The study of '''religion and video games''' is a subfield of [[Religion and the Internet|digital religion]], which the American scholar of communication, [[Heidi Campbell]], defines as "Religion that is constituted in new ways through digital media and cultures." (Campbell, 2012, p. 3).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Heidi|title=Digital Religion: Understanding Religious Practice in New Media Worlds|date=2012|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=978-0415676113|page=288}}</ref> Video games once struggled for legitimacy as a cultural product, today, however, they are both business and art.<ref>{{cite podcast | url= http://www.religiousstudiesproject.com/podcast/video-games-and-religious-studies/ | title= http://www.religiousstudiesproject.com/podcast/video-games-and-religious-studies/ | website= THE RELIGIOUS STUDIES PROJECT | publisher= | host=DAVID MCCONEGHY | date=February 14, 2016 | access-date= March 5, 2018 }}</ref> [[Video game]]s increasingly turn to [[religion]] not just as [[Ornament (art)|ornament]] but as core elements of their [[video game design]] and [[Play (activity)|play]].<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Campbell | first1 = Heidi | last2 = et all | author-link = Heidi Campbel | title = Why Religious Studies Should Pay Attention to Religion in Gaming | journal = Journal of the American Academy of Religion | pages = 1–24 | date = 2015 }}</ref> <ref>{{Citation | last1 = Grieve | first1 = Gregory Price | last2 = et all | author-link = Gregory Price | title = Current Key Perspectives in Video Gaming and Religion | journal = Gameviornments | issue = 3 | url = http://elib.suub.uni-bremen.de/edocs/00104918-1.pdf | date = 2015 }}</ref> <ref>{{Citation | last1 = Grieve | first1 = Gregory Price | author1-link = Gregory Price | last2 = Campbell | first2 = Heidi | author2-link = Heidi Campbell | title = Studying Religion in Digital Gaming. A Critical Review of an Emerging Field | journal = Online – Heidelberg Journal of Religions on the Internet | issue = 5.1 | url = http://heiup.uni-heidelberg.de/journals/index.php/religions/article/view/12183 | date = 2014 }}</ref> Games involve moral decision,<ref>{{cite book |last=Sicart |first=Miguel |date=2011 |title=The Ethics of Computer Games |url=https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/ethics-computer-games |location=Cambridge MA |publisher=MIT Press |page=272 |isbn=9780262516624 |author-link=Miguel Sicart }}</ref> rely on invented religions,<ref> {{cite book |last=Gregory |first=Rabia |editor-last1=Campbell |editor-first1=Heidi |editor-last2=Grieve |editor-first2=Grieve |title=Playing with Religion and Digital Games |publisher=Rou |date=2014 |pages=134–154 |chapter=Chapter 6: Citing The Medieval: Using Religion as World-Building Infrasturcuture in Fantasy |isbn=978--0-253-01253-1}} </ref> and allow users to create and experience virtual religious spaces.<ref>{{cite book |last=Wagner |first=Rachel |date=2012 |title=Godwired: Religion, Ritual and Virtual Reality |location=London |publisher=Routldge |author-link=Rachel Wagner }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Grieve |first=Gregory |date=2016 |title=Cyber Zen: Imagining Authentic Buddhist Identity, Community, and Practices in the Virtual World of Second Life |location=New York |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-0415628730 |author-link=Gregory Price Grieve }}</ref> As one of the newest forms of [[entertainment]], however, there is often [[Video game controversies|controversy]] and [[moral panic]] when video games engage religion,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Reichmuth | first1 = Philip | last2 = Werning | first2 = Stefan | date = 2006 | title = Pixel Pashas, Digital Djinns | url = | journal = ISIM Review | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 46–47 | doi = | pmc = | pmid = | access-date = | name-list-format = vanc }}</ref> for instance, in [[Insomniac Games]]' use of the [[Manchester Cathedral]] in ''[[Resistance: Fall of Man]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Campbell |first1=Heidi | author1-link= Heidi Campbell|last2=Gregory |first2=Gregory Price|author2-link= Gregory Price Grieve|editor-last1=Campbell |editor-first1=Heidi|editor-last2=Grieve |editor-first2=Gregory PRice |title=Playing with Religion and Digital Games |publisher=Indiana University Press |date=2014 |pages=1–21 |chapter=Introduction: What Playing With Religion Offers Digital Games}}</ref> Concepts and elements of contemporary and ancient religions appear in video games in various ways: [[place of worship|places of worship]] are a part of the [[gameplay]] of [[real-time strategy]] games like ''[[Age of Empires]]''; narratively, games sometimes borrow themes from religious traditions like in ''[[Mass Effect 2]]''.
==Defining religion and religious elements==
[[Religion]] has several definitions. [[Organized religion|Religions]] that are [[Religious organization|organized]] can be seen as [[cultural system]]s, with corresponding [[religious behaviour|behavior]] and practice. They often have [[sacred text]]s and [[holy places]]. A [[religious experience]], however, does not necessarily have to be understood through an established religious framework.
Themes and questions about life and death, innocence and guilt and violence are [[Existentialism|existential]] in nature; while they are not immediately understood as "religious", they are about the [[meaning of life]].
==Use of religious elements==
[[Video game developer]]s use religious and spiritual themes to involve the player more deeply in the game.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Testa |first=Alessandro |date= |title= Religion(s) in Videogames Historical and Anthropological Observations |url=http://heiup.uni-heidelberg.de/journals/index.php/religions/issue/view/1449/showToc |journal= Online - Heidelberg Journal of Religions on the Internet |publisher= |volume= 05 |issue= Religion in Digital Games. Multiperspective and Interdisciplinary Approaches|pages= 249–276|doi= 10.11588/rel.2014.0.12170 |access-date=7 March 2016}}</ref> Video game developer [[Shigeru Miyamoto]], who used to play outside as a child, used his experiences and memories of exploring the forest and discovering a Buddhist temple in the design of his video games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2010/12/20/master-of-play |title= Master of Play |last1= Paumgarten |first1=Nick |date=2010-12-20 |website= [[The New Yorker]] |publisher= |access-date= 2016-03-07}}</ref> Canadian developer [[BioWare]] (''[[Mass Effect]]'', ''[[Dragon Age]]'') has in its offices several encyclopedias on religion, as well as the [[Book of the Dead]].<ref name="Bissell">{{cite book |last= Bissell |first= Tom|authorlink=Tom Bissell|date= 2010|title= [[Extra Lives: Why Video Games Matter]] |publisher= Pantheon Books|page=120 |isbn=978-0-307-37870-5}}</ref>
The negative portrayal of religions has been criticized.<ref name="Religion or lack thereof"/>
Religious elements are used in two ways: explicit and implicit. They are seen side-by-side in video games and do not exclude each other.<ref name="Understanding">{{cite book |last1=Clark |first1=Terry Ray |last2= Clanton | first2 = Dan W. |date= 2012 |title= Understanding Religion and Popular Culture: Theories, Themes, Products and Practices|publisher= [[Routledge]]|page= 130 |isbn= 9780415781060}}</ref> Religion in ''Mass Effect'', for instance, can be understood as an "[[unseen character]]".<ref name="auto">Irizarry, J.A. & Irizarry, I.T. The Lord is My Shepard: Confronting Religion in the Mass Effect Trilogy. In Heidbrink, S. en Knoll, T. (ed.) ''Religion in Digital Games. Multiperspective & Interdisciplinary Approaches.'' Volume 05 (2014)</ref>
===Explicit narrative references=== An explicit reference to a religious or spiritual concept is one that is clear to what it is referring.<ref name="Understanding"/> These can be based upon real-world religions, but also on fictional ones. Stories, [[Motif (narrative)|motifs]] and names of characters from [[religious text]]s are used as reference points.
====Ancient religions==== {{see also|Ancient Egyptian deities in popular culture}} Ancient religions and their deities are used in various ways. The religions portrayed are often no longer practiced, like [[ancient Greek religion]].<ref name="Religion or lack thereof"/> In the real-time strategy game ''[[Age of Mythology]]'' the player has to choose a "major god", which gives certain gameplay benefits.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-09-age-of-mythology-extended-edition-review |title=Age of Mythology: Extended Edition review |date=9 May 2014 |work=[[Eurogamer]] |publisher=Gamer Network}}</ref> In ''[[Prince of Persia (2008 video game)|Prince of Persia]]'' the nameless Prince has to fight [[Angra Mainyu|Ahriman]], an evil deity from [[Zoroastrianism]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Crecente, B. |year=2008 |title=Prince of Persia Ditches Roots, Gets a Final Fantasy Make-Over, |accessdate=18 September 2015|url= http://kotaku.com/5011425/prince-of-persia-ditches-roots-gets-a-final-fantasy-make-over}}</ref>
====Events and places==== Real world historical religions and events are used as inspiration for video games. For instance, while ''[[Assassin's Creed (video game)|Assassin's Creed]]'' (2007) is [[historical fiction|fictional]], it is set during the [[Third Crusade]] in the [[Holy Land]]; the player takes on the role of the [[Assassins|Assassin]] [[Altaïr Ibn-La'Ahad]] and is involved in the conflict between Catholic Christians, Orthodox Christians, Sunni Muslims and Shi'ite Muslims.<ref>{{cite web |author=LeJacq, Y. |year=2014 |title=Assassin's Creed Can Actually Teach You A Thing Or Two |url= http://kotaku.com/assassins-creed-can-actually-teach-you-a-thing-or-two-1576446550 |accessdate=2016-04-05}}</ref> While these religions appear, they are portrayed in a "sanitized manner".<ref name="Kotaku Good">{{cite web |url= http://kotaku.com/5509058/religion-in-games-less-a-leap-of-faith-more-a-suspension-of-belief |title= Religion in Games: Less a Leap of Faith, More a Suspension of Belief |last= Good |first= Owen |date= 2010-04-04 |website= [[Kotaku]] |publisher= |access-date= 2016-02-16}}</ref>
====Organizations==== Religion is often institutionalized, having a certain organisational structure. Most games in the ''[[Megami Tensei]]'' series involve a religion, or a cult.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://kotaku.com/5883361/the-rules-of-religion-and-why-the-next-one-just-might-be-a-game |title=The Rules of Religion, and Why The Next One Just Might Be a Game |first=Patricia |last=Hernandez |work=[[Kotaku]] |publisher=[[Gawker Media]]}}</ref>
====Religious violence==== In the action role-playing game ''[[The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim]]'' (2011) a civil war is about to erupt between the Empire and the Stormcloaks.<ref name="auto1">Thames, R. C. Religion as a Resource in Digital Games. In Heidbrink, S. en Knoll, T. (ed.) ''Religion in Digital Games. Multiperspective & Interdisciplinary Approaches.'' Volume 05 (2014)</ref> The Stormcloaks wish to worship Talos, a human ascended to godhood. The Empire suffered a defeat against the powerful Aldmeri Dominion, an alliance of Elves who have made the worship of Talos illegal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/what-happened-between-oblivion-skyrim-a-brief-history/2/ |title=What happened between Oblivion and Skyrim? Here's a brief history |first=Matt |last=Boyd |work=[[GamesRadar]]}}</ref> It is up to the player to help in the conflict.
===Implicit narrative references=== [[Image:Triforce.svg|thumb|right|175px|The [[Triforce]] from [[The Legend of Zelda|''The Legend of Zelda'' series]]. Based upon the concept of [[Mon (badge)|''mon'']], it is a recognizable symbol for the series]] The stories of [[action-adventure]] and [[Role-playing video games|role-playing]] games often involve world-saving quests. The player, as the protagonist, takes on the role of the hero.<ref>[[Jane McGonigal|McGonigal, J]] (2011). ''Reality is Broken: Why Games Make Us Better''. Maven Publishing, Amsterdam. Page 13</ref> The player character is often destined to save the world, which in itself is a [[prophecy]].<ref name="Religion or lack thereof">{{cite web| url= http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/video-game-religions-or-lack-thereof |title=Video Game Religions (or Lack Thereof) |first=Gil |last=Almogi |accessdate=2016-04-21 |date=2014-01-30}}</ref><ref>Slater, A. ''Prophecy, Pre-destination, and Free-from Gameplay The Nerevarine Prophecy in Bethesda's 'Morrowind'". In Heidbrink, S., Knoll, T. and Wysocki, J. (ed.) ''Religion in Digital Games Reloaded. Immersion into the Field''. Volume 07 (2015)</ref>
''[[The Legend of Zelda]]'' uses religious elements and motifs like the [[Triforce]].<ref name="auto1"/><ref>Cuddy, L. (ed.) The Legend of Zelda and Philosophy (2008). Open Court, Chicago. Page 196</ref>
==Video games as a religious medium==
Players and developers use games to express their existential and spiritual feelings. Video games as cultural objects can also provide religious and spiritual experiences, like ''[[Journey (2012 video game)|Journey]]'' (2012).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/community/2013/01/22/can-we-finally-begin-to-consider-video-games-experiences/|title=It's time we consider video games as ‘experiences,’ not mere products|work=[[VentureBeat]]}}</ref> Developer [[Jenova Chen]] said that "I feel that ''Journey'' is a very spiritual game. People from around the world ask me if the game has a religious connection. Many religions share an affinity with ''Journey''—this is because many religions partly share a common structure". Chen said ''Journey'' is based upon [[Joseph Campbell]]'s book on comparative mythology ''[[The Hero with a Thousand Faces]]'' and the [[Monomyth|"Hero's Journey"]] narrative structure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/religion-friendship-and-emotion-a-journey-post-mortem/1100-6367138/|title=Religion, friendship, and emotion: A Journey post-mortem|work=[[GameSpot]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/post/180290-journey-as-ritual/|title='Journey' As Ritual|work=[[PopMatters]]}}</ref>
After the death of [[Leonard Nimoy]], ''[[Star Trek Online]]'' added two statues in his honor,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/03/06/leonard-nimoy-memorials-added-to-star-trek-online?%20|title=Leonard Nimoy Memorials Added to Star Trek Online|first=Luke|last=Karmali|date=6 March 2015|work=[[IGN]]|publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]}}</ref> and ''[[World of Warcraft]]'' added a [[non-player character]] (NPC) based upon [[Robin Williams]] after his death.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/12/robin-williams-to-be-memorialized-in-wow|title=Robin Williams to Be Memorialized in WoW|first=David|last=Witmer|date=12 August 2014|work=[[IGN]]|publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kotaku.com.au/2014/08/apparent-robin-williams-model-found-in-world-of-warcraft/|title=Apparent Robin Williams Models Found In World Of Warcraft|first=Patricia|last=Hernandez|work=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]}}</ref> Developer [[Gearbox Software]] honored a late fan of ''[[Borderlands (video game)|Borderlands]]'', cancer victim Michael John Mamaril, by adding a NPC named after him in [[Borderlands 2|the sequel]]. Additionally, Gearbox posted a eulogy to Mamaril in the voice of the game character Claptrap.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/gearbox-to-honor-late-fan-as-an-npc-in-borderlands-2-215160.phtml|title=Gearbox to honor late fan as an NPC in Borderlands 2|publisher=[[Destructoid]]|first=Tony|last=Ponce|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref> For their game ''[[MechWarrior Online]]'', developer [[Piranha Games]] sold a custom in-game unit called a Jenner, honoring the daughter of a player of the game. [[Canadian dollar|CAD]]122,210 was donated to the Canadian Cancer Society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/online-gamers-donate-122-210-in-memory-of-5-year-old-1.1302334|title=Online gamers donate $122,210 in memory of 5-year-old|date=23 August 2013|work=[[CBC.ca]]}}</ref> Losing his wife Pauline to ovarian cancer, ''[[Minecraft]]'' player "GasBandit" built a memorial for her.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/games/5-Touching-Memorials-Video-Games-70528-p2.html|title=5 Touching Memorials In Video Games|work=Cinema Blend|publisher=Gateway Media}}</ref> When players of the online game ''[[Final Fantasy XIV]]'' heard that fellow gamer "Codex Vahla" was in the hospital on life support, they held a digital [[wake (ceremony)|wake]].<ref>Fahey, M. "FFXIV Community Holds Massive Vigil For A Dying Player" (2014), Retrieved 14 September 2015 on http://kotaku.com/ffxiv-community-holds-massive-vigil-for-a-dying-player-1673823454</ref>
===Religious video games=== {{see also|Christian video game|Islamic Fun}} Some religious groups use video games for education. An example is the Christian game ''[[Left Behind: Eternal Forces]]''. {{Clear}}
===Use of video games in a religious setting=== In May 2012, the [[Exeter Cathedral]] used ''[[Flower (video game)|Flower]]'' during its Sunday service.<ref>Narcisse, E. (2012) A PlayStation 3 Game Will Be Part of a Church Service This Sunday, Retrieved 15 september 2015 on http://kotaku.com/5909361/this-sunday-video-games-go-to-church</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/5/9/3010257/exeter-cathedral-flower-service|title=UK cathedral to use 'Flower' video game as part of upcoming service|first=Andrew|last=Webster|date=9 May 2012|work=[[The Verge]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]]}}</ref>
==Controversies== {{See also|Video game controversy}} Opinions on video games differ from religion and denomination; there are religious groups that use games actively to convert people, while some games are [[List of banned video games|banned]] for religious reasons. Scholars of religious studies are also studying video games, by looking at the game and to the players and their experiences, with games like ''[[Journey (2012 video game)|Journey]]'' Religion is considered a serious real world topic, while video games are an art and entertainment.<ref name="Kotaku Good"/> As such, developers and publishers sometimes take precaution not to offend people's religious beliefs. Religious references in the Japanese role-playing video game series ''[[Final Fantasy]]'' were originally censored for the U.S. release of the games. It was after the franchise switched to Sony's [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] with ''[[Final Fantasy VII]]'' (1997) that the religious references were left largely intact.<ref>Ong, A. The Religions Behind Final Fantasy. History of Computer Game Design: Technology, Culture, and Business March 22, 2001</ref> Ubisoft's ''Assassin's Creed'' series show a disclaimer: {{blockquote| "Inspired by historical events and characters. This work of fiction was designed, developed and produced by a multicultural team of various religious faiths and beliefs."<ref name="Kotaku Good"/>{{efn|In ''[[Assassin's Creed: Syndicate]]'', the words "sexual orientations and gender identities" were added.}}}}
Despite efforts from some companies, there have been incidents with religious groups and video games. The German video game rating board [[Unterhaltungssoftware Selbstkontrolle|USK]] gave ''[[The Binding of Isaac (video game)|The Binding of Isaac]]'' a 16+ rating, considering it "[[Blasphemy|blasphemous]]".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/182380/postmortem_mcmillen_and_himsls_.php?print=1 |title=Postmortem: McMillen and Himsl's ''The Binding of Isaac'' |last=McMillen |first=Edmund |authorlink=Edmund McMillen |date=November 28, 2012 |accessdate=February 17, 2014}}</ref>
===Christianity=== The game ''[[BioShock Infinite]]'' is heavily based on the notion of [[American exceptionalism]] at the turn of the 19th century, and incorporates notions taken from Christianity to support the game's dystopian themes. One aspect of this was the use of [[baptism]]. One developer on [[Irrational Games]] staff expressed strong concern to the lead developer, [[Ken Levine (game developer)|Ken Levine]], that the game's presentation of baptism was highly controversial, leading Levine to with the developer to recast the baptism aspect as a notion of forgiveness rather than a religious tenet.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.officialplaystationmagazine.co.uk/2013/01/18/bioshock-infinite-altered-after-conversations-with-religious-people-on-the-team-says-levine/ | title = Bioshock Infinite altered after "conversations with religious people on the team" says Levine | first = Leon | last = Hurley | date = January 18, 2013 | accessdate = January 20, 2013 | work = [[PlayStation Official Magazine (UK)]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130122031459/http://www.officialplaystationmagazine.co.uk/2013/01/18/bioshock-infinite-altered-after-conversations-with-religious-people-on-the-team-says-levine/ | archivedate = January 22, 2013 | df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamespot.com/news/bioshock-infinites-religious-themes-led-dev-to-consider-quitting-6404620 | title = BioShock Infinite's religious themes led dev to consider quitting | first = Eddie | last = Makuch | date = February 28, 2013 | accessdate = February 28, 2013 | publisher = [[GameSpot]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pcgamer.com/2013/03/01/bioshock-infinite-artist-almost-resigned-over-antagonists-religious-views/ | title = BioShock Infinite artist almost resigned over game's depiction of religion | last = Petitte | first = Omri | date = March 1, 2013 | work= [[PC Gamer]] | accessdate= March 2, 2013 }}</ref> At least one player objected to the final changes, prompting them to request a refund from [[Steam (software)|Steam]].<ref name="kotaku refund">{{Cite web | url = http://kotaku.com/some-dont-like-bioshocks-forced-baptism-enough-to-as-473178476 | title = Some Don't Like BioShock's Forced Baptism. ===Hinduism=== On October 22, 2008, Microsoft announced that ''[[Fallout 3]]'' would not be released in India on the [[Xbox 360]] platform.<ref name="Kotaku-India">{{cite web |url=http://kotaku.com/5067039/fallout-3-not-coming-to-india |title=Fallout 3 Not Coming To India |publisher=Kotaku |date=2008-10-22 |accessdate=2010-04-20 |first=Mike |last=Fahey}}</ref> Religious and cultural sentiments were cited as the reason.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/fallout-3-withheld-from-india |title=Fallout 3 withheld from India |publisher=Games Industry |accessdate=2009-12-01 |first=Jason |last=Lee |date=2008-10-22}}</ref> Although the specific reason was not revealed in public, it is possible that it is because the game contains two-headed mutated cows called Brahmin, or that [[Brahmin]] is also the name of an ancient, powerful hereditary caste of [[Hindu]] priests and religious scholars in India, or its similarity to the spelling of [[brahman (cattle)|brahman]], a type of cow that originated in India. Brahman, a breed of [[Zebu]], are revered by Hindus.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinemablend.com/games/Are-Brahmin-The-Reason-For-Fallout-3-s-Cancellation-in-India-12947.html |title=Are Brahmin The Reason For Fallout 3's Cancellation in India? |publisher=Gaming Blend |accessdate=2011-09-04 |date=2008-10-22 |first=Pete |last=Haas}}</ref>
The action game ''Hanuman: Boy Warrior'' was criticized by Rajan Zed, president of the Universal Society of Hinduism, for portraying the Hindu deity [[Hanuman]]. Developed and published in India by Aurona Technologies, the player controls Hanuman. "Controlling and manipulating Lord Hanuman with a joystick/button/keyboard/mouse [is] denigration", said Zed. "Lord Hanuman was not meant to be reduced to just a 'character' in a video game to solidify [a] company/product's base in the growing economy of India." He urged Sony, the publisher of the game, to pull the game. Sony's regional manager however said that ''Hanuman: Boy Warrior'' sold beyond their expectations.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/114224/Hindu_Statesman_Criticizes_Sonys_Hanuman_Boy_Warrior.php |title=Hindu Statesman Criticizes Sony's Hanuman: Boy Warrior |website=[[Gamasutra]] |accessdate=2016-02-16 |date=2009-04-20 |first=Leigh |last=Alexander}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://kotaku.com/5217826/indias-first-game-gets-indias-first-game-controversy |title=India's First Game Gets India's First Game Controversy |website=[[Kotaku]] |accessdate=2016-02-16 |date=2009-04-18 |first=Owen |last=Good}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gamepolitics.com/2009/04/17/hindus-protest-ps2-game-released-india/|title=Hindus Protest PS2 Game Released in India|work=GamePolitics|date=2009-04-17|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420175535/http://www.gamepolitics.com/2009/04/17/hindus-protest-ps2-game-released-india|archivedate=2009-04-20}}</ref>
Zed was also critical of the use of [[Hindu deities]] in the [[Multiplayer online battle arena|MOBA]] game ''[[Smite (video game)|Smite]]''. In response, developer [[Hi-Rez Studios]] COO Todd Harris said that ''Smite'' would still be featuring Hindu deities, possibly adding more. GameSpot asked if characters based upon Abrahamic religions would be added as well, but Harris said that "the key Abrahimic figures—Adam, Noah, Moses, Jesus, Mohammed, are not that interesting in character design or gameplay".<ref>Connor Sheridan on June 29, 2012, http://www.gamespot.com/articles/deity-based-moba-smite-will-not-use-jewish-christian-islamic-figures/1100-6384974/</ref>

However, no actual complaints regarding the music were made.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://community.eu.playstation.com/t5/LittleBigPlanet/very-urgent-about-little-big-planet-lbp/td-p/5627909 |date=16 October 2008 |author=yasser (solid08) |title=very urgent about little big planet lbp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140601131006/http://community.eu.playstation.com/t5/LittleBigPlanet/very-urgent-about-little-big-planet-lbp/td-p/5627909 |archivedate=1 June 2014}}</ref> The song, entitled "Tapha Niang", was by [[Mali]]an artist [[Toumani Diabaté]], himself a devout Muslim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/technology/machinist/blog/2008/10/20/islam_sony| title = Sony recalls LittleBigPlanet over Quran quote in music | date = 20 October 2008 | accessdate=2 January 2010 | publisher=Machinist: Salon.com | first = Cyrus | last = Farivar}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/feb/21/worldmusic|title=The generation game – Music – The Guardian|date=21 February 2008|accessdate=20 October 2008|publisher=The Guardian | first = Robin | last = Denselow | location=London}}</ref> The game was patched twice, the day before its release for players who had received the game early, before its intended release date. ===Sikhism=== ''[[Hitman 2: Silent Assassin]]'' (2002) sparked controversy due to a level featuring the killing of [[Sikh]]s within a depiction of their most holy site, the [[Harmandir Sahib]], where hundreds of Sikhs [[1984 anti-Sikh riots|were massacred in 1984]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/sci_tech/newsid_2440000/2440713.stm |title=Young Sikhs force changes to Hitman 2 |publisher=[[CBBC]] |date=21 November 2002|accessdate=28 January 2008}}</ref> An altered version of ''Silent Assassin'' was eventually released with the related material removed from the game.
==Religion and violence== A study released by the University of Missouri stated that video games often emphasize the violent aspects of religion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5888663/study-says-video-games-have-problematized-view-of-religion|title=Study Says Video Games Have 'Problematized' View of Religion|first=Jason|last=Schreier|work=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]}}</ref> Researcher Greg Perreault said "It doesn't appear that game developers are trying to purposefully bash organized religion in these games, I believe they are only using religion to create stimulating plot points in their story lines".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munews.missouri.edu/news-releases/2012/0227-video-games-depict-religion-as-violent-problematized-mu-study-shows/|title=Video Games Depict Religion as Violent, Problematized, MU Study Shows|publisher=MU News Bureau}}</ref>
==Games as focus of religious studies== {{main|Game studies}}
For many years video games were seen as mere [[entertainment]], a form of "low culture".<ref>Mäyrä, F. An Introduction to Game Studies (2008). SAGE Publications. Page 30</ref> Playing video games was seen as a form of [[escapism]]<ref>Cuddy, L. (ed.) The Legend of Zelda and Philosophy (2008). Open Court, Chicago. Page 58</ref> and the medium was not regarded as a valid object of scientific research. To "play" games as a scholarly pursuit was thought of as "ludicrous".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://criticalreligion.org/2013/10/21/here-be-dragons-the-quest-for-academic-credibility/|title=Here Be Dragons: the quest for academic credibility|work=The Critical Religion Association}}</ref> It has only been in recent years that video games have become the object of scientific study.<ref>Newman, J. Videogames (2012). Routledge. Page 10</ref> Looking at the game as an object, researchers can explore religious and spiritual references. Video game research is done in two ways; the game can be studied as an [[object (philosophy)|object]], while [[actant|actor-focused]] research looks at the player.
===Game-immanent approach=== Video games, as products of human culture, can be seen and read as "[[Text (literary theory)|texts]]". They carry myths, stories and symbols of the time in which they were created.<ref name="auto2">Campbell, H. (ed.). Digital Religion: Understanding Religious Practice in New Media Worlds (2012). Rutledge. Page 145</ref> By "reading" video games, philosophers, sociologists and theologians have the opportunity to study the religious and spiritual themes in video games.<ref>Campbell, H. A. en Grieve, G. P. Studying Religion in Digital Gaming. A Critical Review of an Emerging Field. In Heidbrink, S. en Knoll, T. (ed.) Religion in Digital Games. Multiperspective & Interdisciplinary Approaches. Volume 05 (2014)</ref> This can be done in several ways.
*by studying the design, rules and mechanics or by talking to the developers *by watching others play (e.g. [[Let's Play (video gaming)|Let's Play videos]]) *by playing the game themselves<ref>[[Espen Aarseth]]</ref>
===Player-focused approach===
Video games are [[Interactivity|interactive]]; it requires input from the player to happen. While a video game developer designs the game, including its rules and story, it is up to the player to make the game "happen".<ref>{{cite book |editor-first=Luke |editor-last=Cuddy |title=The Legend of Zelda and Philosophy: I Link Therefore I Am |date=2008 |publisher=Open Court |location=Chicago |page=119}}</ref><ref name="auto2"/> As such, it is up to individual player to give [[Meaning (existential)|meaning]] to their experience.<ref>{{cite book |last=Newman |first=James |title=Videogames |date=2012 |publisher=Routledge |page=14}}</ref>
Video games allow the player to think, form and possibly change their own opinion about religious and spiritual matters.<ref name="auto"/> Players often discuss these elements on online platforms. For instance, some players made their own version of the player character [[Commander Shepard]] of the ''[[Mass Effect]]'' series an atheist, while others thought of him/her{{efn|Commander Shepard can be female or male.}} as a Christian.<ref>Knoll, T. "Are Those the Only Two Solutions?" In Heidbrink, S., Knoll, T. Wysocki, J. (ed.) Religion in Digital Games Reloaded. Immersion into the Field. Volume 07 (2015)</ref> As such, video games also give new meaning to the concept of religion.<ref name="auto1"/>

'''Schismogenesis''' literally means "creation of division". The term derives from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] words σχίσμα ''skhisma'' "cleft" (borrowed into English as [[Schism (religion)|schism]], "division into opposing factions"), and γένεσις ''genesis'' "generation, creation" (deriving in turn from ''gignesthai'' "be born or produced, creation, a coming into being").
==Concepts== ===In anthropology=== The concept of schismogenesis was developed by the [[anthropology|anthropologist]] [[Gregory Bateson]] in the 1930s, to account for certain forms of social behavior between groups among the [[Iatmul people]] of the [[Sepik River]]. Bateson first published the concept in 1935,<ref name="CCS">Bateson, Gregory (1935) Culture Contact and Schismogenesis, Man, Vol. 35 (Dec) pp.178-183</ref><ref name="SEM">Bateson, Gregory (1972) [[Steps to an Ecology of Mind]], Chandler Publishing Company</ref> but elaborated on schismogenesis in his classic 1936 ethnography ''Naven: A Survey of the Problems suggested by a Composite Picture of the Culture of a New Guinea Tribe drawn from Three Points of View'', reissued with a new Epilogue in 1958.<ref>Bateson, Gregory. 1936. Naven: A Survey of the Problems Suggested by a Composite Picture of the Culture of a New Guinea Tribe Drawn from Three Points of View. Cambridge; Cambridge University Press; Second Edition, with a Revised Epilogue, 1958, Stanford: Stanford University Press.</ref> The word "naven" refers to an honorific ceremony among the Iatmul (still practiced) whereby certain categories of kin celebrate first-time cultural achievements. In a schematic summary, Bateson focused on how groups of women and groups of men (especially the honorees mothers' brothers) seemingly inverted their everyday, gendered-norms for dress, behavior, and emotional expression. For the most part, these groups of people belonged to different patrilineages who not only did not regularly renew their marriage alliances, but also interacted through the mode he called schismogenesis. Men and women, too, interacted in this mode. And thus the naven ritual served to correct schismogenesis, enabling the society to endure.<ref>See Eric Kline Silverman, 2001, Masculinity, Motherhood, and Mockery: Psychoanalyzing Culture and the Iatmul Naven Rite in New Guinea. Ann Arbor: The University of Michigan Press.</ref>
In his 1936 book ''Naven'', Bateson defined schismogenesis as "a process of differentiation in the norms of individual behaviour resulting from cumulative interaction between individuals" (p. 175). He continued:
"It is at once apparent that many systems of relationship, either between individuals or groups of individuals, contain a tendency towards progressive change. If, for example, one of the patterns of cultural behaviour, considered appropriate in individual A, is culturally labelled as an assertive pattern, while B is expected to reply to this with what is culturally regarded as submission, it is likely that this submission will encourage a further assertion, and that this assertion will demand still further submission. We have thus a potentially progressive state of affairs, and unless other factors are present to restrain the excesses of assertive and submissive behaviour, A must necessarily become more and more assertive, while B will become more and more submissive; and this progressive change will occur whether A and B are separate individuals or members of complementary groups."
"Progressive changes of this sort we may describe as complementary schismogenesis. But there is another pattern of relationships between individuals or groups of individuals which equally contains the germs of progressive change. If, for example, we find boasting as the cultural pattern of behaviour in one group, and that the other group replies to this with boasting, a competitive situation may develop in which boasting leads to more boasting, and so on. This type of progressive change we may call symmetrical schismogenesis" (pp. 176-77).
Somewhat analogous to [[Émile Durkheim]]'s concepts of mechanical and organic solidarity (see [[functionalism (sociology)|functionalism]]), Bateson understood the symmetrical form of schismogenic behavior among Iatmul men to be one of a competitive relationship between categorical equals (e.g., rivalry). Thus one man, or a group of men, boast, and another man/group must offer an equal or better boast, prompting the first group to respond accordingly, and so forth. Complementary schismogenesis among the Iatmul was seen by Bateson between mainly men and women, or between categorical unequals (e.g., dominance and submission). Men would act dominant, leading women to act submissive, to which men responded with more dominance, and so forth. In both types of schismogenesis, the everyday emotional norms or [[ethos]] of Iatmul men and women prevented a halt to schismogenesis. The crux of the matter for Bateson was that, left unchecked, either form of schismogensis would cause Iatmul society simply to break apart. Thus some social or cultural mechanism was needed by society to maintain social integration. That mechanism among the Iatmul was the naven rite. Bateson's specific contribution was to suggest that certain concrete ritual behaviors either inhibited or stimulated the schismogenic relationship in its various forms.<ref>For a more elaborate discussion of the concept among the Iatmul, see the section "Early Work: New Guinea and Bali" in [[Gregory Bateson]].</ref>
===In natural resource management=== Bateson's treatment of conflict escalation has been used to explain how conflicts arise over natural resources, including human-predator conflicts in Norway<ref name="BROX">Brox, Ottar. (2000) "Schismogenesis in the Wilderness: The Reintroduction of Predators in Norwegian Forests." Ethnos, Vol. 65 (3) pp.387–404. doi:10.1080/00141840050198045. </ref> and also for conflicts among stakeholder groups in shared fisheries,<ref name="HLHPAL">Harrison, Hannah L., and Philip A. Loring. (2014) “Larger Than Life: The Emergent Nature of Conflict in Alaska’s Upper Cook Inlet Salmon Fisheries.” SAGE Open, Vol. 4, pp.1–14. http://sgo.sagepub.com/content/4/4/2158244014555112</ref> In the latter case, Harrison and Loring compare conflict schismogenesis to the [[Tragedy of the Commons]], arguing that it is a similar kind of escalation of behavior also caused by the failure of [[social institutions]] to ensure equity in fisheries management outcomes.
===In music=== [[Steven Feld]] (1994, p. 265-271), apparently in response to [[R. Murray Schafer]]'s ''[[schizophonia]]'' and borrowing the term from Bateson, employs ''schismogenesis'' to name the recombination and recontextualization of sounds split from their sources.
==Types==
Bateson, in ''Steps to an Ecology of Mind'' describes the two forms of schismogenesis and proposes that both forms are self-destructive to the parties involved. He goes on to suggest that researchers look into methods that one or both parties may employ to stop a schismogenesis before it reaches its destructive stage.
===Complementary schismogenesis===
The first type of schismogenesis is best characterized by a [[class struggle]], but is defined more broadly to include a range of other possible social phenomena. Given two groups of people, the interaction between them is such that a behavior ''X'' from one side elicits a behavior ''Y'' from the other side, The two behaviors complement one another, exemplified in the dominant-submissive behaviors of a class struggle. Furthermore, the behaviors may exaggerate one another, leading to a severe rift and possible conflict. Conflict can be reduced by narrowing [[information asymmetries]] between the two groups.
===Symmetrical schismogenesis===
The second type of schismogenesis is best shown by an [[arms race]]. The behaviors of the parties involved elicit similar or symmetrical behaviors from the other parties. In the case of the [[United States]] and the [[Soviet Union]], each party continually sought to amass more nuclear weapons than the other party, a clearly fruitless but seemingly necessary endeavor on both sides.
A form of symmetrical schismogenesis exists in common sporting events, such as [[baseball]], where the rules are the same for both teams.
==Interpersonal communication== In the field of [[communication]], complementary schismogenesis is a force that can take effect in a [[conversation]] where people have different conversational styles, "creating a split in a mutually aggravating way".<ref name="TNWIM">Tannen, Deborah. [[That's Not What I Meant!]], Random House Publishing.</ref> The effect causes two well-meaning individuals having a conversation to ramp up different styles, resulting in a disagreement that does not stem from actual difference of opinion. For example, if one person's conversational style favoured louder voices, while the other favoured softer speech, the first person might increase the loudness in their voice while the other spoke softer and softer, each trying to lead the conversation towards their style's conception of normal talking.<ref name="TNWIM" /><ref name="FSTS">Feld, Steven (1994) "From Schizophonia to Schismogenesis..." In Music Grooves, edited by Charles Keil and Steven Feld, 257-289. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press.</ref> <ref name="HSSS">Tannen, Deborah (2004) “He Said, She Said; Exploring the Different Ways Men and Women Communicate” Portable Professor: Linguistics. Barnes & Noble Audio Lecture Series.</ref>
==Systems of holding back== Systems of holding back are also a form of schismogenesis. They are defined as "mutually aggregating spirals which lead people to hold back contributions they could make because others hold back contributions they could make."<ref name="Si1">Hämäläinen, R. P., & Saarinen, E. 2007. [http://www.sal.hut.fi/Publications/pdf-files/rham07a.pdf Systems Intelligent Leadership]. In R. P. Hämäläinen & E. Saarinen (Eds.), Systems Intelligence in Leadership and Everyday Life: 3-38, Espoo: Helsinki University of Technology, Systems Analysis Laboratory.</ref>
In [[Systems intelligence]] literature, it is held that human interaction has a tendency to fall into such systems unless conscious effort is made to counter this tendency. For example, although most managers would want to give support to their team and most team members would like to receive such support many times support does not result. This is because both parties might feel that the other party is not giving enough and thus they will themselves hold back what they in the best case could give. It has been suggested that systems of holding back are "the single most important key to life-decreasing, reciprocity-trivializing and vitality-downgrading mechanisms in human life." <ref name="Si2">Saarinen, E., & Hämäläinen, R. P. 2007. [http://www.sal.hut.fi/Publications/pdf-files/rham07b.pdf Systems Intelligence: Connecting Engineering Thinking with Human Sensitivity]. In R. P. Hämäläinen & E. Saarinen (Eds.), Systems Intelligence in Leadership and Everyday Life: 39-50, Espoo: Helsinki University of Technology, Systems Analysis Laboratory.</ref>

{{tone|date=June 2012}} '''School violence''' encompasses physical violence, including student-on-student fighting and [[corporal punishment]]; [[Psychological abuse|psychological violence]], including verbal abuse; [[sexual violence]], including rape and sexual harassment; many forms of [[bullying]], including [[cyberbullying]]; and carrying weapons in school.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002469/246970e.pdf|title=School Violence and Bullying: Global Status Report|last=UNESCO|first=|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2017|isbn=978-92-3-100197-0|location=|pages=9, 110–111}}</ref> It is widely held to have become a serious problem in recent decades in many countries, especially where weapons such as guns or knives are involved. It includes [[violence]] between school students as well as physical attacks by students on school staff.
==Risk factors==
===Internalizing and externalizing behaviors===
A distinction is made between internalizing and externalizing behavior. Internalizing behaviors reflect withdrawal, inhibition, anxiety, and/or [[depression (mood)|depression]]. Internalizing behavior has been found in some cases of youth violence although in some youth, depression is associated with substance abuse. Because they rarely act out, students with internalizing problems are often overlooked by school personnel.<ref name="Christie">Christie, C.A., Nelson, C.M., & Jolivet, K. (2005). [http://www.edjj.org/focus/prevention/plr.pdf ''Prevention of antisocial and violent behavior in youth: A review of the literature''.] Lexington, KY: University of Kentucky. Retrieved 2009-05-01.</ref> Externalizing behaviors refer to delinquent activities, aggression, and hyperactivity. Unlike internalizing behaviors, externalizing behaviors include, or are directly linked to, violent episodes. Violent behaviors such as punching and kicking are often learned from observing others.<ref>Bandura, A. (1983). Psychological mechanisms of aggression. In R. G. Geen & E. I. Donnerstein (Eds.), ''Aggression: Theoretical and empirical reviews''. New York: Academic. {{ISBN|0-12-278801-X}}</ref><ref name="akers">{{cite journal | last1 = Akers | first1 = R. L. | last2 = Krohn | first2 = M. D. | last3 = Lanza-Kaduce | first3 = L. | last4 = Radosevich | first4 = M. | year = 1979 | title = Social learning and deviant behavior: A specific test of a general theory | url = | journal = American Sociological Review | volume = 44 | issue = 4| pages = 635–655 |pmid = 389120 | doi=10.2307/2094592}}</ref> Just as externalizing behaviors are observed outside of school, such behaviors also observed in schools.<ref name="Christie"/>
===Other individual factors===
A number of other individual factors are associated with higher levels of aggressiveness. Compared to children whose antisocial conduct begins in adolescence, early starters have a worse prognosis in terms of future aggression and other antisocial activities.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1017/S0954579498001734 | last1 = Patterson | first1 = G. R. | last2 = Forgatch | first2 = M. S. | last3 = Yoerger | first3 = K. L. | last4 = Stoolmiller | first4 = M. | year = 1998 | title = Variables that initiate and maintain an early-onset trajectory for juvenile offending | url = | journal = Developmental Psychopathology | volume = 10 | issue = 3| pages = 531–547 }}</ref> Lower IQ is related to higher levels of aggression.<ref name = "Hirschi & Hindelang"/><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.52.1.232 | last1 = Huesmann | first1 = L. R. | last2 = Eron | first2 = L. D. | last3 = Yarmel | first3 = P. W. | year = 1987 | title = Intellectual functioning and aggression | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 52 | issue = 1| pages = 232–240 | pmid = 3820075 }}</ref><ref name="Loeber">{{cite journal | last1 = Loeber | first1 = R. | last2 = Farrington | first2 = D. P. | last3 = Stouthamer-Loeber | first3 = M. | last4 = Moffitt | first4 = T. E. | last5 = Caspi | first5 = A.| last6 =Lynam | year = 1998| first6 =Don | title = The development of male offending: Key findings from the first decade of the Pittsburgh Youth Study | url = | journal = Clinical Child and Family Psychology Review | volume = 7 | issue = 4 | pages = 273–297 | doi = 10.1023/A:1013574903810 }}</ref> Other findings indicate that in boys early problematic motor skills, attentional difficulties, and reading problems predict later persistent antisocial conduct.<ref name="Moffitt">{{cite journal | doi = 10.2307/1130972 | last1 = Moffitt | first1 = T. E. | year = 1990 | title = Juvenile delinquency and attention deficit disorder: Boys' developmental trajectories from age 3 to age 15 | jstor = 1130972| journal = Child Development | volume = 61 | issue = 3| pages = 893–910 | pmid = 2364762 }}</ref>
===Home environment=== The home environment is thought to contribute to school violence. The Constitutional Rights Foundation suggests long-term exposure to [[gun]] violence, parental [[alcoholism]], [[domestic violence]], physical abuse of the child, and child sexual abuse teaches children that criminal and violent activities are acceptable.<ref name="CRE">Constitutional Rights Foundation. (1997). [http://www.crf-usa.org/school-violence/causes-of-school-violence.html ''Causes of school violence'']. Retrieved on April 20, 2009.</ref> Harsh parental discipline is associated with higher levels of aggressiveness in youth.<ref name="Sampson"/> There is some evidence indicating that exposure to [[television violence]]<ref>Bushman, B. J., & Huesmann, L. R. (2001). Effects of televised violence on aggression. In D. G. Singer & J. L. Singer (Eds.), ''Handbook of children and the media'' (pp. 223–254). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. {{ISBN|0-7619-1954-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1177/009365094021004004 | last1 = Paik | first1 = H. | last2 = Comstock | first2 = G. | year = 1994 | title = The effects of television violence on antisocial behavior: A meta-analysis | url = | journal = Communication Research | volume = 21 | issue = 4| pages = 516–546 }}</ref> and, to a lesser extent, violent video games<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/1467-9280.00366 | last1 = Anderson | first1 = C. A. | last2 = Bushman | first2 = B. J. | year = 2001 | title = Effects of violent video games on aggressive behavior, aggressive cognition, aggressive affect, physiological arousal, and prosocial behavior: A meta-analytic review of the scientific literature | url = | journal = Psychological Science | volume = 12 | issue = 5| pages = 353–359 | pmid = 11554666 }}</ref> is related to increased aggressiveness in children, which, in turn, may carry over into school.
Straus adduced evidence for the view that exposure to parental [[Corporal punishment in the home|corporal punishment]] increases the risk of aggressive conduct in children and adolescents.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1525/sp.1991.38.2.03a00010 | last1 = Straus | first1 = M. A. | year = 1991 | title = Discipline and deviance: Physical punishment of children and violence and other crime in adulthood | url = | journal = Social Problems | volume = 38 | issue = 2| pages = 133–154 }}</ref> Straus's findings have been contested by Larzelere<ref>Larzelere, R. (1997). [http://people.biola.edu/faculty/paulp/CritiqueStraus.html ''Critique of anti-spanking study'']. Biola University.</ref> and [[Diana Baumrind|Baumrind]].<ref>[http://www.fractaldomains.com/devpsych/baumrind.htm ''Words from Diana Baumrind on corporal punishment'']. (1998).</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0033-2909.128.4.580 | last1 = Baumrind | first1 = D. | last2 = Larzelere | first2 = R. | last3 = Cowan | first3 = P. | year = 2002 | title = Ordinary physical punishment: Is it harmful? Comment on Gershoff (2002) | url = http://www.apa.org/journals/releases/bul1284580.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 128 | issue = 4| pages = 580–589 | pmid = 12081082 }}</ref> A [[meta-analysis]] of the vast literature on corporal punishment, however, indicates that corporal punishment is related to poorer outcomes in children and youth.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0033-2909.128.4.539 | last1 = Gershoff | first1 = E. T. | year = 2002a | title = Corporal punishment by parents and associated child behaviors and experiences: A meta-analytic and theoretical review | url = | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 128 | issue = 4| pages = 539–579 | pmid = 12081081 }}</ref> The methodologically soundest studies indicate "positive, moderately sized associations between parental corporal punishment and children’s aggression."<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0033-2909.128.4.602 | last1 = Gershoff | first1 = E. T. | year = 2002b | title = Corporal punishment, physical abuse, and the burden of proof: Reply to Baumrind, Larzelere, and Cowan (2002), Holden (2002), and Parke (2002) | url = | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 128 | issue = 4| pages = 602–611 }}</ref> Gershoff found that the trajectory of mean effect sizes (the size of the effect of corporal punishment on children's problem behavior) was curvilinear with the largest mean effect size in middle school (''M'' = 0.55; on average the mean of corporal punishment group was more than half a standard deviation higher than the mean of the non-punishment group) and slightly smaller effect sizes in grade school (''M'' = 0.43) and high school (''M'' = 0.45).
Gerald Patterson's social interactional model, which involves the mother's application and the child's counterapplication of ''coercive'' behaviors, also explains the development of aggressive conduct in the child.<ref name="Patterson">Patterson, G. (1982). ''Coercive family process''. Eugene, OR: Castalia. {{ISBN|0-916154-02-5}}</ref><ref>Patterson, G. R. (1995). Coercion as a basis for early age of onset for arrest. In J. McCord (Ed.), ''Coercion and punishment in long-term perspectives'' (pp. 81–105). New York: Cambridge University Press.</ref> In this context, coercive behaviors include behaviors that are ordinarily punishing (e.g., whining, yelling, hitting, etc.). Abusive home environments can inhibit the growth of social cognitive skills needed, for example, to understand the intentions of others.<ref name="CRE"/><ref name="Dodge, Pettit">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0021-843X.104.4.632 | last1 = Dodge | first1 = K. A. | last2 = Pettit | first2 = G. S. | last3 = Bates | first3 = J. E. | last4 = Valente | first4 = E. | year = 1995 | title = Social information processing patterns partially mediate the effect of early physical abuse on later conduct problems | url = | journal = Journal of Abnormal Psychology | volume = 104 | issue = 4| pages = 632–643 | pmid = 8530766 }}</ref> Short-term longitudinal evidence is consistent with the view that a lack of social cognitive skills [[Mediation (statistics)|mediates]] the link between harsh parental discipline and aggressive conduct in kindergarten.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.2307/1131558 | last1 = Weiss | first1 = B. | last2 = Dodge | first2 = K. A. | last3 = Bates | first3 = J. E. | last4 = Pettit | first4 = G. S. | year = 1992 | title = Some consequences of early harsh discipline: Child aggression and a maladaptive social information processing style | jstor = 1131558| journal = Child Development | volume = 63 | issue = 6| pages = 1321–1335 | pmid = 1446555 }}</ref> Longer-term, follow-up research with the same children suggests that partial mediating effects last until third and fourth grade.<ref name="Dodge, Pettit"/> Hirschi's (1969) control theory advances the view that children with weak affective ties to parents and school are at increased risk of engaging in delinquent and violent behavior in and out of school.<ref name="Hirschi">Hirschi, T.W. (1969). ''Causes of delinquency''. Berkeley: University of California Press. {{ISBN|0-520-01487-1}}</ref> Hirschi's [[cross-sectional study|cross-sectional]] data from northern California high-school students are largely consistent with this view.<ref name="Hirschi"/> Findings from [[case-control study|case-control]]<ref name="Sampson">Sampson, R., & Laub, J. (1993). ''Crime in the making: Pathways and turning points through life''. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press. {{ISBN|0-674-17604-9}}</ref> and [[longitudinal study|longitudinal studies]]<ref name="Borowsky">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1367/1539-4409(2002)002<0475:VRAPFA>2.0.CO;2 | last1 = Borowsky | first1 = I. W. | last2 = Ireland | first2 = M. | last3 = Resnick | first3 = M. D. | year = 2002 | title = Violence risk and protective factors among youth held back in school | url = | journal = Ambulatory Pediatrics | volume = 2 | issue = 6| pages = 475–484 | pmid = 12437395 }}</ref><ref name="Wiesner">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1023/B:JOYO.0000037635.06937.13 | last1 = Wiesner | first1 = M. | last2 = Windle | first2 = M. | year = 2004 | title = Assessing covariates of adolescent delinquency trajectories: A latent growth mixture modeling approach | url = | journal = Journal of Youth and Adolescence | volume = 33 | issue = 5| pages = 431–442 }}</ref> are also consistent with this view.
===Neighbourhood environment=== Neighbourhoods and communities provide the context for school violence. Communities with high rates of crime and drug use teach youth the violent behaviors that are carried into schools.<ref name="CRE"/><ref name="Evans">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0003-066X.59.2.77 | last1 = Evans | first1 = G. W. | year = 2004 | title = The environment of childhood poverty | url = | journal = American Psychologist | volume = 59 | issue = 2| pages = 77–92 | pmid = 14992634 }}</ref><ref>Gottfredson, G. D., & Gottfredson, D. C. (1985). ''Victimization in schools''. New York: Plenum. {{ISBN|0-306-42023-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Johnson | first1 = S.L. | last2 = Burke | first2 = J.G. | last3 = Gielen | first3 = A.C. | year = 2011 | title = Prioritizing the school environment in school violence prevention efforts | url = | journal = Journal of School Health | volume = 81 | issue = 6| pages = 331–340 | pmid = 21592128 | doi = 10.1111/j.1746-1561.2011.00598.x | pmc = 4697272 }}</ref> Children in violent neighborhoods tend to perceive that their communities are risky, and that these feelings of vulnerability carry over to the school environment.<ref name="Tack 224–248">{{Cite journal|last=Tack|first=Anjanette M. Chan|date=February 2017|title=Making Friends in Violent Neighborhoods: Strategies among Elementary School Children|url=|journal=Sociological Science|volume=4|pages=224–248|via=}}</ref> Dilapidated housing in the neighbourhood of the school has been found to be associated with school violence.<ref name="limbos"/> Teacher assault was more likely to occur in schools located in high-crime neighbourhoods.<ref name="Casteel">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1002/ajim.20520 | last1 = Casteel | first1 = C. | last2 = Peek-Asa | first2 = C. | last3 = Limbos | first3 = M.A. | year = 2007 | title = Predictors of nonfatal assault injury to public school teachers in Los Angeles City | url = | journal = American Journal of Industrial Medicine | volume = 50 | issue = 12| pages = 932–939 | pmid = 17979131 }}</ref> Exposure to deviant peers is a risk factor for high levels of aggressivity.<ref name="akers"/><ref name="Loeber"/> Research has shown that [[poverty]] and high population densities are associated with higher rates of school violence.<ref name="Evans"/> Well controlled [[longitudinal study|longitudinal research]] indicates that children's exposure to community violence during the early elementary school years increases the risk of aggression later in elementary school, as reported by teachers and classmates.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/1467-8624.00623 | last1 = Guerra | first1 = N. G. | last2 = Huesmann | first2 = L. R. | last3 = Spindler | first3 = A. | year = 2003 | title = Community violence exposure, social cognition, and aggression among urban elementary school children | url = | journal = Child Development | volume = 74 | issue = 5| pages = 1561–1576 | pmid = 14552414 }}</ref> Other, well controlled longitudinal research that utilized [[propensity score matching]] indicates that exposure to gun violence in early adolescence is related to the initiation of serious physical violence in later adolescence.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.1110096 | last1 = Bingenheimer | first1 = J. B. | last2 = Brennan | first2 = R. T. | last3 = Earls | first3 = F. J. | year = 2005 | title = Firearm violence exposure and serious violent behavior | url = | journal = Science | volume = 308 | issue = 5726| pages = 1323–1326 | pmid = 15919997 }}</ref> Neighbourhood gangs are thought to contribute to dangerous school environments. Gangs use the social environment of the school to recruit members and interact with opposing groups, with gang violence carrying over from neighbourhoods into some schools.<ref>Wolfgang, M.E., Figlio, R.M., & Sellin, T. (1987). ''Delinquency in a birth cohort''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. {{ISBN|0-226-90553-5}}</ref> Alternatively, many children who grow up in violent neighborhoods learn to deliberately find and make "street-oriented" friends as an instrumental tactic used to avoid being victimized.<ref name="Tack 224–248"/> Without the threat of violence, children more commonly develop friendships based on homophily, or shared traits.
===School environment=== Recent research has linked the school environment to school violence.<ref name="limbos"/><ref name="meyer">{{cite journal | last1 = Meyer-Adams | first1 = N. | last2 = Conner | first2 = B.T. | year = 2008 | title = School violence: Bullying behaviors and the psychosocial school environment in middle schools | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_7200/is_200810/ai_n32297587/pg_9/ | journal = Children and Schools | volume = 30 | issue =4 | pages = 211–221 | doi=10.1093/cs/30.4.211}}{{dead link|date=August 2014}}</ref> Teacher assaults are associated with a higher percentage male faculty, a higher proportion of male students, and a higher proportion of students receiving free or reduced cost lunch (an indicator of poverty).<ref name="Casteel"/> In general, a large male population, higher grade levels, a history of high levels of disciplinary problems in the school, high student to [[teacher]] ratios, and an urban location are related to violence in schools.<ref name=limbos>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1746-1561.2008.00341.x | last1 = Limbos | first1 = M.A.P. | last2 = Casteel | first2 = C. | year = 2008 | title = Schools and neighborhoods: Organizational and environmental factors associated with crime in secondary schools | url = | journal = Journal of School Health | volume = 78 | issue = 10| pages = 539–544 | pmid = 18808473 }}</ref><ref>Larsen, E. (2003). [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/1b/99/86.pdf ''Violence in US public schools'']. ERIC Identifier: ED482921</ref> In students, academic performance is inversely related to antisocial conduct.<ref name = "Hirschi & Hindelang">{{cite journal | doi = 10.2307/2094556 | last1 = Hirschi | first1 = T. | last2 = Hindelang | first2 = M. J. | year = 1977 | title = Intelligence and delinquency: A revisionist review | jstor = 2094556| journal = American Sociological Review | volume = 42 | issue = 4| pages = 571–587 | pmid = 900659 }}</ref><ref name="CDC"/> The research by Hirschi<ref name="Hirschi"/> and others,<ref name="Sampson"/><ref name="Borowsky"/><ref name="Wiesner"/> cited above in the section on the home environment, is also consistent with the view that lack of attachment to school is associated with increased risk of antisocial conduct.
==Prevention and intervention== The goal of prevention and intervention strategies is to stop school violence from occurring. According to the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]], there are at least four levels at which violence-prevention programs can act: at the level of society in general, the school community, the family, and the individual.<ref>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2006). [https://www.cdc.gov/ncipc/duip/spotlite/SafeYouthSafeSchools.htm School health policies and programs study]. Retrieved on April 20, 2009.</ref>
*''Society-level prevention strategies'' aim to change social and cultural conditions in order to reduce violence regardless of where the violence occurs. Examples include reducing [[media violence research|media violence]], reshaping social [[norm (sociology)|norms]], and restructuring [[education|educational systems]].<ref name=CDC>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.[https://www.cdc.gov/HealthyYouth/shpps/2006/factsheets/pdf/FS_ViolencePrevention_SHPP2006.pdf/ "School Health Policies and Programs Study 2006"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, 2008. Retrieved April 20, 2009.</ref> The strategies are rarely used and difficult to implement. **Now Is The Time is a federal initiative developed in 2013 in response to the growing number of gun related school violence incidents. The initiative will provide funding and resources to schools in an effort to reduce gun violence in schools. Funding will be provided for implementation of school interventions and training teachers and staff, programs that will support the mental and physical health of students, conflict resolution programs to reduce further school violence, and restoration of school environment after a violent incident.<ref>Examining School Safety and Gun Violence in America. (2014). Curriculum Review, 54(4), 8-9</ref> *''[[School Based Prevention Programs|School-wide strategies]]'' are designed to modify the school characteristics that are associated with violence. An avenue of [[Occupational health psychology#Workplace incivility and violence|psychological research]] is the reduction of violence and incivility, particularly the development of interventions at the level of the school.<ref name="Schon">Schonfeld, I.S. (2006). School violence. In E.K. Kelloway, J. Barling, & J.J. Hurrell, Jr. (Eds). [http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED494566.pdf ''Handbook of workplace violence''] (pp. 169–229). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0962-1849(05)80077-0 | last1 = Howard | first1 = K. A. | last2 = Flora | first2 = J. | last3 = Griffin | first3 = M. | year = 1999 | title = Violence-prevention programs in schools: State of the science and implications for future research | url = | journal = Applied & Preventive Psychology | volume = 8 | issue = 3| pages = 197–215 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Scheckner | first1 = S. | last2 = Rollin | first2 = S. A. | last3 = Kaiser-Ulrey | first3 = Cheryl| last4 = Wagner | first4 = R. | year = 2002 | title = School Violence in children and adolescents: A meta-analysis of the effectiveness of current interventions | url = | journal = [[Journal of School Violence]] | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages = 5–32 | doi = 10.1300/J202v01n02_02 }}</ref> The CDC suggests schools promote classroom management techniques, [[cooperative learning]], and close student supervision.<ref name="CDC"/><ref>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2008). [https://www.cdc.gov/ncipc/dvp/CPTED.htm Using environmental design to prevent school violence]. Retrieved April 20, 2009.</ref> At the elementary school level, the group behavioral intervention known as the Good Behavior Game helps reduce classroom disruption and promotes prosocial classroom interactions.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0193-3973(93)90013-L | last1 = Dolan | first1 = L. J. | last2 = Kellam | first2 = S. G. | last3 = Brown | first3 = C. H. | last4 = Werthamer-Larsson | first4 = L. | last5 = Rebok | first5 = G. W. | last6 = Mayer | first6 = L. W. |display-authors=etal | year = 1993 | title = The short-term impact of two classroom-based preventive interventions on aggressive and shy behaviors and poor achievement | url = | journal = Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology | volume = 14 | issue = 3| pages = 317–345 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1023/A:1020977107086 | last1 = Embry | first1 = D. D. | year = 2002 | title = The Good Behavior Game: A best practice candidate as a universal behavioral vaccine | url = | journal = Clinical Child and Family Psychology Review | volume = 5 | issue = 4| pages = 273–296 | pmid=12495270}}</ref> There is some evidence that the Second Step curriculum, which is concerned with promoting impulse control and empathy among second and third graders, produces reductions in physically aggressive behavior.<ref>{{cite journal|name-list-format=vanc| doi = 10.1001/jama.277.20.1605 | last1 = Grossman | first1 = D. C. | last2 = Neckerman | first2 = H. J. | last3 = Koepsell | first3 = T. D. | last4 = Liu | first4 = P. Y. | last5 = Asher | first5 = K. N. | last6 = Beland | first6 = K. | last7 = Frey | year = 1997 | first7 = K | last8 = Rivara | first8 = FP | title = Effectiveness of a violence prevention curriculum among children in elementary school: A randomized controlled trial | url = | journal = Journal of the American Medical Association | volume = 277 | issue = 20| pages = 1605–1611 | pmid = 9168290 }}</ref> Other school-wide strategies are aimed at reducing or eliminating bullying<ref>Olweus, D. (1991). Bully/victim problems among schoolchildren: Basic facts and effects of a school-based intervention. In D. Pepler & K. Rubin (Eds.), ''The development and treatment of childhood aggression'' (pp. 411–448). Hillsdale, NJ: Erlbaum.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-7610.1994.tb01229.x | last1 = Olweus | first1 = D. | year = 1994 | title = Annotation: Bullying at school: Basic facts and effects of a school-based intervention program | url = | journal = Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, and Allied Disciplines | volume = 35 | issue = 7| pages = 1171–1190 | pmid = 7806605 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Olweus | first1 = D. | year = 1997 | title = Bully/victim problems in school: Knowledge base and an effective intervention program | url = | journal = Irish Journal of Psychology | volume = 18 | issue = | pages = 170–190 |issn=0303-3910 | doi=10.1080/03033910.1997.10558138}}; Also reprinted as {{cite journal | last1 = Olweus | first1 = DAN | title = Bullying at School: Knowledge Base and an Effective Intervention Program | journal = Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences | volume = 794 | pages = 265–276 | year = 1996 | doi = 10.1111/j.1749-6632.1996.tb32527.x }}</ref><ref>Olweus, D. (1999). The nature of school bullying: A cross-national perspective. In P. K. Smith, J. Junger-Taqs, D. Olweus, R. Catalano, & P. Slee (Eds.), ''The nature of school bullying: A cross-national perspective'' (pp. 7–27). New York: Plenum.</ref> and organizing the local police to better combat gang violence.<ref>Young, B. (2009, Mar. 2). [http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/PrintStory.pl?document_id=2008800988&zsection_id=2003925728&slug=gangsandschools02m&date=20090302 Seattle schools scramble to outsmart gangs]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ''Seattle Times''.</ref><ref>[http://talglobal.com/downloads/TAL_Global-CEB-Short_Case_Study.pdf TAL Global's CEB Case Study.]</ref> **The implementation of ''school-wide early-warning systems'', the school equivalent of a [[Distant Early Warning Line|DEW Line]]-like surveillance operation designed to "prevent the worst cases of school violence," has been problematic.<ref name="Schon"/> Recent developments in early threat assessment, however, show promise.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1080/15388220.2010.519432 | pmid = | title = Development, Evaluation, and Future Directions of the Virginia Student Threat Assessment Guidelines | year = 2011 | last1 = Cornell | first1 = Dewey | last2 = Allen | first2 = Korrie | journal = [[Journal of School Violence]] | volume = 10 | pages = 88–106 }}</ref> Violence-prevention efforts can also be usefully directed at developing anti-bullying programs, helping teachers with classroom-management strategies, applying behavioral strategies such as the Good Behavior Game, implementing curricular innovations such as the Second Step syllabus, developing programs to strengthen families (see below), and implementing programs aimed at enhancing the social and academic skills of at-risk students (see below). * Teachers are the professional group who works directly where school bullying takes place and who spends the most time with both bullies, victims and bystanders. Thus, whether and how teachers intervene in the case of bullying is of great importance. Research has shown that teachers prefer authority-based interventions towards bullies but seem to neglect to support the victims.<ref name="Burger 2015 191–202">{{cite journal| last = Burger| first = Christoph| last2 = Strohmeier| first2 = Dagmar| last3 = Spröber| first3 = Nina| last4 = Bauman| first4 = Sheri| last5 = Rigby| first5 = Ken| date = 2015| title = How teachers respond to school bullying: An examination of self-reported intervention strategy use, moderator effects, and concurrent use of multiple strategies.| url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tate.2015.07.004| journal = Teaching and Teacher Education |volume=51| pages = 191–202| doi = 10.1016/j.tate.2015.07.004 }}</ref> Unfortunately, most teacher training curricula do not include preventive and interventive skills regarding school violence.<ref name="Burger 2015 191–202"/>
*Some intervention programs are aimed at ''improving family relationships''.<ref name="CDC"/> There is some evidence that such intervention strategies have modest effects on the behavior of children in the short<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-006X.66.5.715 | last1 = Webster-Stratton | first1 = C. | year = 1998 | title = Preventing conduct problems in Head Start children: Strengthening parenting competencies | url = | journal = Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology | volume = 66 | issue = 5| pages = 715–730 | pmid = 9803690 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-006X.63.4.560 | last1 = Tremblay | first1 = R. E. | last2 = Pagani-Kurtz | first2 = L. | last3 = Mâsse | first3 = L. C. | last4 = Vitaro | first4 = F. | last5 = Pihl | first5 = R. O. | year = 1995 | title = A bimodal preventive intervention for disruptive kindergarten boys: Its impact through mid-adolescence | url = | journal = Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology | volume = 63 | issue = 4| pages = 560–568 | pmid = 7673533 }}</ref> and long term.<ref>{{cite journal|name-list-format=vanc| doi = 10.1001/jama.280.14.1238 | last1 = Olds | first1 = D. | last2 = Henderson | first2 = C. R. Jr. | last3 = Cole | first3 = R. | last4 = Eckenrode | first4 = J. | last5 = Kitzman | first5 = H. | last6 = Luckey | first6 = D. | last7 = Pettitt | year = 1998 | first7 = L | last8 = Sidora | first8 = K | last9 = Morris | first9 = P | last10 = Powers | first10 = Jane | title = Long-term effects of nurse home visitation on children's criminal and antisocial behavior: 15-year follow-up of a randomized controlled trial | url = | journal = Journal of the American Medical Association | volume = 280 | issue = 14| pages = 1238–1244 | pmid = 9786373 | display-authors = 8 }}</ref> Patterson's home intervention program involving mothers has been shown to reduce aggressive conduct in children.<ref name="Patterson"/> An important question concerns the extent to which the influence of the program carries over into the child's conduct in school. *Some prevention and intervention programs focus on ''individual-level strategies''. These programs are aimed at students who exhibit [[aggression]] and violent behaviors or are at risk for engaging in such behaviors. Some programs include [[conflict resolution]] and team problem-solving.<ref name="CDC"/> Other programs teach students [[social skill]]s.<ref name="bennet">{{cite journal | last1 = Bennett-Johnson | first1 = E. | year = 2004 | title = The root of school violence: Causes and recommendations for a plan of action | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0FCR/is_2_38/ai_n6130139 | journal = College Student Journal | volume = 38 | issue = | pages = 199–202 }}</ref> The Conduct Problems Prevention Research Group, while developing and implementing a universal anti-aggression component for all elementary school children, also developed and implemented a separate social-skills and academic tutoring component that targets children who are the most at risk for engaging in aggressive behavior.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-006X.67.5.631 | last1 = Conduct Problems | first1 = Prevention Research Group | year = 1999a | title = Initial Impact of the Fast Track Prevention Trial for Conduct Problems: I. The High-Risk Sample | journal = Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology | volume = 67 | issue = 5| pages = 631–647 | pmid = 10535230 | pmc = 2762610 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-006X.67.5.648 | last1 = Conduct Problems | first1 = Prevention Research Group | year = 1999b | title = Initial Impact of the Fast Track Prevention Trial for Conduct Problems: II. Classroom Effects | url = | journal = Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology | volume = 67 | issue = 5| pages = 648–657 | pmid = 10535231 | pmc = 2761630 }}</ref> * Bullying prevention programs such as Olweus provides materials for educators that will train them on how to mediate a bullying situation as well as procedures to take if a child is suicidal.
== Challenges in measuring violence in schools == Research on violence affecting children in schools is challenging for a variety of reasons.<ref name=":0" />
=== Methodological issues === When trying to measure the scope of violence in schools and to find out about the types of violence experienced by students, some key issues include: from what categories of the school community to collect the data; what data should be collected from each categories; and using which methods. For example, should there be studies or surveys where researchers ask students directly about violence in school, through self-reports about the violence they experienced as targets or perpetrators? Or should they be asked about incidents of violence that they have witnessed as bystanders? Should any of these questions be asked via self-administered questionnaires or questionnaires administered by researchers in schools? Does it make more sense to collect this data outside of schools, for example, through household surveys? Or through online surveys where students have access to the internet? Or is it better to rely on mechanisms for reporting incidents of violence in educational institutions when they are available, either in the schools themselves or outside schools (governmental hotlines, internet-based reporting systems, police and justice sectors, etc.)? What questions can be asked of children, using terminology that is easy to understand, age-appropriate and culturally sensitive?<ref name=":0" />
=== Legal and ethical issues === In most countries there are strict rules related to research involving children, as they are under the age of consent. Therefore, requesting informed consent from the children in a study involves their parents and guardians. Asking children about violence, and particularly violence they have experienced themselves, can be traumatic. Finally, researching [[Education and the LGBT community|issues related to sexual orientation and gender identity/orientation in education]] and in relation to children has additional challenges. In some contexts it is not legal to discuss these issues either in schools or even outside of schools. Where it is legal, it may be considered as a very sensitive topic to be discussed with children and young people. Asking children and young people questions related to their sexual orientation and gender identity in the school setting is ethically questionable, as it could embarrass them and expose them to stigma and discrimination, unless questions are asked in strict confidence and anonymity is granted by independent researchers external to schools.<ref name=":0" />
