'''Social network aggregation''' is the process of collecting content from multiple [[social network service]]s, such as [[Instagram]], [[Tumblr]], [[Flickr]], [[LinkedIn]], [[Twitch.tv|Twitch]], [[YouTube]], [[List of social networking websites|etc.]] into one unified presentation. The task is often performed by a social network aggregator (such as [[Hootsuite]], [https://taggbox.com Taggbox] and [[FriendFeed]]), which pulls together information into a single location,<ref name=king>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/jun2007/tc20070615_141976.htm |title=When Your Social Sites Need Networking |accessdate=2008-04-10 |author=Rachael King |date=2007-06-18 |work=[[BusinessWeek]]}}</ref> or helps a user consolidate multiple social networking profiles into one profile.<ref name=mashable>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2007/07/17/social-network-aggregators/ |title=20 Ways To Aggregate Your Social Networking Profiles |accessdate=2008-04-10 |author=Stan Schroeder |date=2007-07-17 |publisher=[[Mashable]]}}</ref> Various aggregation services provide tools or [[GUI widget|widgets]] to allow users to consolidate messages, track friends, combine bookmarks, search across multiple social networking sites, read [[RSS feed]]s for multiple social networks, see when their name is mentioned on various sites, access their profiles from a single interface, provide "lifestreams", etc.<ref name=mashable/> Social network aggregation services attempt to organize or simplify a user's social networking experience,<ref>{{cite journal|title=Upstart websites aim to consolidate social networking |author=Beth Snyder Bulik |date=2007-06-18 |publisher=[[Advertising Age]] |quote= The latest trend in the space is aggregation-websites...[which] all present variations on the theme of organizing or simplifying a consumer's social-networking experience. }}</ref> although the idea has been satirized by the concept of a "social network aggregator aggregator".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbspot.com/News/2008/03/social-network-aggregator-aggregator-launched.html |title=Social Network Aggregator Aggregator AllMyFrickingFriends.com Launched |accessdate=2008-04-10 |author=Brian Briggs |date=2008-03-17 |publisher=[[BBSpot]]}}</ref>
There are other related uses of social media aggregators aside from simplifying the user's social networking experiences. Some aggregators are designed to help companies (and bloggers) improve engagement with their brand(s) by creating aggregated social streams that can be embedded into an existing website and customized to look visually intrinsic to the site. This allows potential customers to interact with all the social media posts maintained by the brand without requiring them to jump from site to site. This has the benefit of keeping customers on the brand's site for a longer period of time (increasing "time on site" metrics).
==Social network aggregators== Social network aggregation platforms allow social network members to share social network activities like [[Twitter]], [[YouTube]], [[Stumbleupon]], [[Digg]], [[Delicious (website)|Delicious]], with other major platforms. All content appears in real time to other members who subscribe to a particular community, which eliminates the need to jump from one [[social media]] network to another, trying to keep an eye on one's interests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tech.justmoved.in/2008/04/01/social-aggregation-defragment-your-online-life/|title=Social Aggregation: defragment your online life|date=April 1, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091229172414/http://tech.justmoved.in/2008/04/01/social-aggregation-defragment-your-online-life/|archivedate=December 29, 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Social network aggregation systems can rely on initiation by publishers or by readers. In the publisher-initiated aggregation systems, the publishers combine their own identities, which make their readers see all aggregated content once subscribed. In the reader-initiated systems (such as [[Windows Phone 7]] people hub<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.microsoft.com/windowsphone/en-us/features/default.aspx|title=Windows Phone 7 Features|accessdate=2011-11-11 |author=Microsoft |work=[[Microsoft]]}} </ref> and Linked Internet UI<ref> {{cite web|url=http://research.nokia.com/page/5457 |title= Linked Internet UI Concept|accessdate=2011-11-11 |author=Nokia |date=2009-09-02 | work= [[Nokia]]}} </ref>), the readers combine the identities of others, which has no impact on the publishers or other readers. The publishers can still keep separate identities for different readers.
Technically, the aggregation is enabled by [[API]]s provided by social networks. For the API to access a user's actions from another platform, the user will have to give permission to the social-aggregation platform, by specifying the user-id and password of the social media to be syndicated. This concept resembles [[open ID]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://alchemi.co.uk/archives/hum/aggregation_of_.html |title=Aggregation of data across social networks |accessdate=2008-04-10 |author=David Jennings |date=2005-08-03 |publisher=alchemi.co.uk}}</ref> In March 2008, ''[[The Economist]]'' reported that [[social network service]]s are only beginning the move away from "walled gardens" to more open architectures. Some sites are working together on a "data portability workgroup", while others are focusing on a single sign-on system called [[OpenID]] to allow users to log on across multiple sites. Historically, the trend from private services to more open ones can be seen across many Internet services from email and instant messaging to the move that early [[online service provider]]s made to become websites.<ref name=economist>{{cite web|url=http://www.economist.com/business/displaystory.cfm?story_id=10880936 |title=Everywhere and nowhere |accessdate=2008-04-10 |date=2008-03-19 |publisher=[[The Economist]]}}</ref> The [[OpenSocial]] initiative aims to bridge the member overlap between various online social network services.<ref name=alexp>{{cite web|url=http://blog.compete.com/2007/11/12/connecting-the-social-graph-member-overlap-at-opensocial-and-facebook/ |title=Connecting the Social Graph: Member Overlap at OpenSocial and Facebook |accessdate=2008-04-10 |author=Alex Patriquin |date=2007-11-12 |publisher=[[Compete.com]] blog}}</ref>
==Overlap between multiple social-network services== The attraction of social network aggregation comes from the fact that some users tend to use multiple social networks: they have accounts on several social-networking sites.<ref name="economist"/> In November 2007, Alex Patriquin of [[Compete.com]] reported on the member overlap between various online social network services:<ref name="alexp"/>
{|class="wikitable sortable" ! Site!![[Bebo]]!![[Facebook]]!![[Friendster]]!![[Hi5 (website)|Hi5]]!![[LinkedIn]]!![[MySpace]]!![[Ning (website)|Ning]]!![[Orkut]]!![[Plaxo]] |- ! Bebo | {{Percentage bar|100}} || {{Percentage bar|25}} || {{Percentage bar|2}} || {{Percentage bar|3}} || {{Percentage bar|1}} || {{Percentage bar|65}} || {{Percentage bar|1}} || {{Percentage bar|0}} || {{Percentage bar|0}} |- ! A 2009 study of 11,000 users<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/who_uses_social_networks_and_what_are_they_like_part_1.php |title=Who Uses Social Networks and What Are They Like? (Part 1) |work=[[ReadWrite]]Web |date=July 9, 2009 |accessdate=September 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120622083248/http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/who_uses_social_networks_and_what_are_they_like_part_1.php |archivedate=June 22, 2012 |df= }} </ref> reported that the majority of [[MySpace]], [[LinkedIn]], and [[Twitter]] users also have [[Facebook]] accounts.

A '''sociocultural system''' is a "human [[population]] viewed (1) in its ecological context and (2) as one of the many [[subsystems]] of a larger [[ecological systems|ecological system]]".<ref>Nanda, Serena (1984). ''Cultural Anthropology, second edition.'' Stamford, Connecticut: [[Cengage Learning|Wadsworth Publishing Company]] (Cengage Learning). {{ISBN|978-0-534-02749-0}}</ref> [[File:SCSdiagram.jpg|thumb|350px|Conceptual Model of a Sociocultural System.]] The term "sociocultural system" embraces three concepts: society, culture, and system. A society is a number of interdependent organisms of the same species. A culture is the learned behaviors that are shared by the members of a society, together with the material products of such behaviors. The words "society" and "culture" are fused together to form the word "sociocultural". A system is "a collection of parts which interact with each other to function as a whole".<ref>Kauffman, Draper L. (1980). ''Systems One: An Introduction to Systems Thinking.'' Minneapolis, MN: Future Systems Inc. {{ISBN|978-99962-805-1-1}}</ref> The term sociocultural system is most likely to be found in the writings of anthropologists who specialize in [[ecological anthropology]].
In 1979, Marvin Harris outlined a universal structure of sociocultural systems. He mentioned [[infrastructure]] (production and population), structure (which is behavioural, like corporations, political organizations, hierarchies, castes), and a [[base and superstructure|superstructure]] (which is mental, like beliefs, values, norms).<ref>Elwell, Frank W., 2013, "Harris on the Universal Structure of Society," Retrieved 2015-02-15, http://www.faculty.rsu.edu/~felwell/Theorists/Essays/Harris1.htm</ref><ref>[http://www.aupress.ca/index.php/books/120219 Sociocultural Systems:Principles of Structure and Change], Frank W. Elwell, CC BY-NC-ND 2.5 CA.</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Systems science}} *[[Conrad Kottak]] *[[Cultural system]] *[[Marvin Harris]] *[[Roy Rappaport]] *[[Societal collapse]] *[[Sustainability]] *[[Systems theory]] *[[Systems thinking]] *[[Zeitgeist]]

revision.text:
[[File:1864 Dower Map of the Western United States - Geographicus - WesternUSA-dower-1864.jpg|thumb|1864 Dower hand-colored map depicting the western half of the United States, including most of the lands west of the Mississippi River]] This '''timeline of the American Old West''' is a chronology ordered list of events significant to the development of the American West as a region of the United States prior to 1912. The term "[[American Old West]]" refers to a vast geographical area and lengthy time period of imprecise boundaries, and historians' definitions vary. The events in this timeline occurred primarily in the contiguous portion of the modern United States west of the [[Mississippi River]], and mostly in the period between the [[Louisiana Purchase]] in 1803 and the admission of the last [[contiguous United States|mainland states]] into the Union in 1912. A small section summarizing early exploration and settlement prior to 1803 is included to provide a foundation for later developments. Rarely, events significant to the history of the West but which occurred within the modern boundaries of Canada and Mexico are included as well. Western North America was inhabited for millennia by various groups of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]], and later served as a [[frontier]] to European powers, beginning with [[Spain|Spanish]] colonization in the 16th century. [[United Kingdom|British]], [[France|French]], and [[Russia]]n claims followed in the 18th and 19th centuries. After the [[American Revolution]], the newly independent [[United States]] began securing [[American frontier|its own frontier]] from the [[Appalachian Mountains]] westward for settlement and economic investment by American citizens. The long [[territorial evolution of the United States|history of American expansion]] into these lands has played a central role in shaping American culture, iconography, and the modern national identity, and remains a popular topic for study by scholars and historians. Events listed below are notable developments for the region as a whole, not just for a particular state or smaller subdivision of the region; as historians Hine and Faragher put it, they "tell the story of the creation and defense of communities, the use of the lands, the development of markets, and the formation of states.... It is a tale of conquest, but also one of survival, persistence, and the merging of peoples and cultures."{{cite book|last1=Hine|first1=Robert V.|last2=Faragher|first2=John Mack|title=The American West : a new interpretive history|date=2000|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Conn.|isbn=0300078358|page=10.}} ==Early exploration and settlement== [[File:Coronado-Remington.jpg|thumb|''Coronado Sets Out to the North'' by American artist [[Frederic Remington]]]] [[File:The Capitol - Po' Pay.jpg|thumb|Statue of [[Popé]], or ''Po'Pay'', leader of the [[Pueblo Revolt]] in 1680, as it stands in the [[National Statuary Hall]] in the U.S. [[United States Capitol|Capitol Building]]]] [[File:Primitive plow.jpg|thumb|Natives utilize a primitive plow to prepare a field for planting near [[Mission San Diego de Alcalá]]. Drawing by A.B. Dodge, 1920.]] For almost three centuries after Columbus' voyages to the New World, much of western North America remained unsettled by European colonists, despite various territorial claims made by imperialist nations. Europeans interest in the vast territory was motivated by the search for precious metals, especially gold, and the fur trade, with miners, trappers, and hunters among the first people of European descent to permanently settle in the West.{{rp|150}} The early years were also a period of scientific exploration and survey, such that by 1830 the rough outline of the western half of the continent had been mapped to the [[Pacific Ocean]].Robert M. Utley, ed. (2003) ''The Story of The West'' DK Publishing, New York {{ISBN|0-7894-9660-7}}.{{rp|162}} {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=1|1540||Feb 23||[[Kingdom of Spain|Spanish]] [[conquistador]] [[Francisco Vázquez de Coronado]] embarks on an expedition into the unexplored territory north of [[Viceroyalty of New Spain|colonized Mexico]] to search for the fabled [[Seven Cities of Gold]]. The voyage lasts more than two years, during which Coronado travels through much of the [[Southwestern United States|American Southwest]] and as far north as present-day [[Kansas]]. His party is the first to document the geography and [[Native Americans in the United States|indigenous peoples]] of significant portions of the West.Winship, George Parker, translator and editor. ''The Journey of Coronado 1540–1542''. Golden, CO: Fulcrum Publishing, 1990. Introduction by Donald C. Cutter. {{ISBN|1-55591-066-1}} |- |rowspan=1|1579||Jun 17||[[Kingdom of England|English]] explorer [[Francis Drake]] lands his expedition on the Pacific coast of North America in present-day [[Drakes Bay]], [[California]], claiming all of the land not already under Spanish control for England.{{cite web|url=http://www.drakenavigatorsguild.org/press.html |title=Drake Navigator's Guild |publisher=Drakenavigatorsguild.org |date=17 October 2012 |accessdate=25 October 2012}} |- |rowspan=1|1598||Apr||Spanish explorer [[Juan de Oñate]] establishes [[Santa Fe de Nuevo México|Nuevo México]] in the region around the upper [[Rio Grande]] as the northernmost province of [[New Spain]], serving as its first [[List of Spanish governors of New Mexico|colonial governor]].{{cite book|last1=Weber|first1=David J.|title=The Spanish frontier in North America|date=1992|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven|isbn=0300059175|page=77|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KOPdX2qaVrkC&lpg=PA83&pg=PA77#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=27 October 2015}} |- |rowspan=1|1607|| ||[[New Spain|Spanish colonists]] establish the city of [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]] in the province of [[Santa Fe de Nuevo México]].{{cite web|url=http://www.santafenm.gov/index.asp?NID=601|title=Santa Fe – A Rich History|accessdate=October 12, 2008|publisher=City of Santa Fe|archive-url=https://archive.is/20121214025742/http://www.santafenm.gov/index.asp?NID=601|archive-date=2012-12-14|dead-url=yes|df=}} |- |rowspan=1|1610|| ||The [[Palace of the Governors]] is built in Santa Fe, the new capital of [[Santa Fe de Nuevo México|Nuevo México]]. Today it is the oldest continuously occupied public building in the United States.{{cite web|title=New Mexico's Palace of the Governors|publisher=C-SPAN|date=January 7, 2013|url=http://www.c-span.org/video/?310647-1/new-mexicos-palace-govenors|accessdate=18 Apr 2015}} |- |rowspan=1|1680||Aug 10||An alliance of [[Puebloan peoples]] coordinated by [[Popé]] initiates [[Pueblo Revolt|a mass revolt]] against Spanish colonists occupying what is now northern [[New Mexico]] in an effort to abolish European influence in the area. More than 400 people are killed and the Spanish are unable to reconquer Santa Fe for another 12 years.{{cite book|last1=Weber|first1=David J.|editor1-last=Milner|editor1-first=Clyde A., II|editor2-last=O'Connor|editor2-first=Carol A.|editor3-last=Sandweiss|editor3-first=Martha A.|title=The Oxford history of the American West|date=1994|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|pages=55–56|chapter=The Spanish–Mexican Rim}} |- |rowspan=1|1692|| ||Santa Fe is formally repossessed by the Spanish after [[Diego de Vargas]] negotiates a peace with the [[Puebloan peoples|Pueblo]] Indians. The following six years witness a difficult reinstatement of Spanish and Franciscan rule over the Pueblos, including another revolt in 1696, which is successfully countered by De Vargas and his forces.{{cite book|last1=Hine|first1=Robert V.|last2=Faragher|first2=John Mack|title=The American West : a new interpretive history|date=2000|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Conn.|isbn=0300078358|page=37.}}{{cite book|last1=Weber|first1=David J.|title=The Spanish frontier in North America|date=1992|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Conn.|isbn=0300059175|pages=137–141|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KOPdX2qaVrkC&lpg=PA245&pg=PA246#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=28 October 2015}} |- |rowspan=1|1718||May 1||The [[Presidio San Antonio de Bexar]], eventually the city of [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]], is founded in [[Spanish Texas]] to undermine French claims in the area.{{cite news | author=[[Adina Emilia De Zavala]]| date=December 8, 1917| url=https://archive.org/details/historylegendsof00dezarich|title=History and legends of The Alamo and others missions in and around San Antonio| publisher=History legends of de Zarichs Online| accessdate= June 2, 2014|page=8}} |- |rowspan=1|1743||Mar 30||[[François de La Vérendrye|François]] and [[Louis-Joseph Gaultier de La Vérendrye]], on expedition west from [[Quebec]], bury an inscribed lead plate near present-day [[Fort Pierre, South Dakota]], claiming the area for [[Kingdom of France|France]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/pierre_fortpierre/verendrye_site_pierre.html|website=[[National Park Service]]|title=Vérendrye Museum|accessdate=March 12, 2015}} |- |rowspan=1|1759||Oct 7||A Spanish [[Battle of the Twin Villages|attack on a fortified Indian village]] along the [[Red River of the South|Red River]] in what is now [[Texas]] is repulsed and defeated by allied [[Wichita people|Wichita]], [[Comanche]], and [[Tonkawa]] tribes.Allen, Henry Easton. "The Parrilla Expedition to the Red River in 1759". ''The Southwestern Historical Quarterly'', Vol. 43, No. 1 (July 1939), p. 65. |- |rowspan=1|1762||Nov 13||[[Louis XV of France|France]] transfers all of [[Louisiana (New France)|its territory]] west of the [[Appalachian Mountains]] to [[Charles III of Spain|Spain]] in [[Treaty of Fontainebleau (1762)|a secret treaty]] just months prior to the negotiations that end the [[Seven Years' War|French and Indian War]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/4397/|title=The Present State of the West-Indies: Containing an Accurate Description of What Parts Are Possessed by the Several Powers in Europe|website=[[World Digital Library]]|year=1778|accessdate=2013-08-30}} |- |rowspan=1|1769||Jul 16||Spanish [[Franciscan]]s, led by friar [[Junípero Serra]], establish [[Mission San Diego de Alcalá]] in [[The Californias|Las Californias]]. By 1823, the missionaries successfully plant a [[Spanish missions in California|series of 20 more missions]] along the coast of what becomes the Spanish province of [[Alta California]]. These missions bring European culture to the [[indigenous peoples of California]], but also enable a serious decline of from one-third to one-half of the indigenous population there during the Mission period.{{cite book|last1=Weber|first1=David J.|title=The Spanish frontier in North America|date=1992|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Conn.|isbn=0300059175|page=246|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KOPdX2qaVrkC&lpg=PA245&pg=PA246#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=27 October 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Nugent|first1=Walter|title=Into the West : the story of its people|date=1999|publisher=Alfred A. Knopf|location=New York|isbn=0679454799|pages=33–35|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0AvI-biS6EsC&lpg=PP1&dq=Into%20the%20West%20Google%20books&pg=PA33#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=27 October 2015}} |- |rowspan=1|1775||Aug 20||A company of Spanish soldiers establishes a site for the [[Presidio San Agustín del Tucsón]] in what is now [[Tucson, Arizona]]. |- |rowspan=1|1776||Jul 29||Two Franciscan priests lead the [[Dominguez-Escalante expedition|Domínguez–Escalante expedition]] west from Santa Fe in an attempt to find an overland route to the Spanish Catholic mission in [[Monterey, California|Monterey]]. Though they fail to reach [[Las Californias]], they explore previously unknown areas of the [[Colorado Plateau]], become the first Europeans to enter the [[Great Basin]], and establish the eastern section of what will later become the [[Old Spanish Trail (trade route)|Old Spanish Trail]].{{cite web |title=Dominguez and Escalante Expedition, 1776 |url=http://www.uintahbasintah.org/jdandemain.htm |publisher=UintahBasintah.org |accessdate=June 7, 2017}} cites: {{Citation |last1=Chavez |first1=A |last2=Waner |first2=T |year=1995 |title=The Dominguez and Escalante Journal|publisher=University of Utah Press |location=Salt Lake City}} |- |rowspan=1|1779||Sep 3||[[Comanche people|Comanche]] Indian leader [[Cuerno Verde]] is killed in combat with Spanish forces led by [[Juan Bautista de Anza]] in what is now [[Pueblo County, Colorado]].{{cite book|last=Martinez|year=2004|title=Anza and Cuerno Verde|pages=23, 52}} |- |rowspan=1|1783||Sep 3||The [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|Treaty of Paris]] is signed by the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] and the [[United States of America]], ending the [[American Revolutionary War]]. |- |rowspan=1|1792||May 19||Captain [[George Vancouver]]'s [[Vancouver Expedition|expedition]] drops anchor near present-day [[Seattle]] and proceeds to name [[Puget Sound]], [[Mount Rainier]], [[Vashon Island]], and Restoration Point. Vancouver and his expedition are the first Europeans to explore the area, claiming it for the [[United Kingdom|British]] along with much of the [[Pacific Northwest]] coast, including [[Vancouver Island]] and the [[Columbia River]].{{cite web|last1=Rochester|first1=Junius|title=Vancouver, George (1758–1798)|url=http://www.historylink.org/index.cfm?DisplayPage=output.cfm&File_Id=5359|website=HistoryLink.org|accessdate=5 November 2015|date=4 March 2003}}{{cite book|last1=Schwantes|first1=Carlos Arnaldo|title=The Pacific Northwest : an interpretive history|date=1996|publisher=Univ. of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln|isbn=0803242255|pages=49–50|edition=Rev. and enl.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JImlIbueaXcC&lpg=PA160&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=5 November 2015}} |} {{clear}} ==1800s== [[File:Frank bond 1912 louisiana and the louisiana purchase.jpg|right|thumb|"Louisiana" and the Louisiana Purchase
Government Printing Office, 1912 Map No. 4]] [[File:Lewis and Clark.jpg|thumb|[[Meriwether Lewis]] and [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]]]] {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=1|1800||Oct 1||Under pressure from [[Napoléon Bonaparte]], the [[Charles IV of Spain|Kingdom of Spain]] transfers the colony of [[Louisiana (New Spain)|Louisiana]] back to the [[French First Republic|French Republic]] with the secret [[Third Treaty of San Ildefonso]]. |- |rowspan=2|1803||Apr 1||The United States [[Louisiana Purchase|agrees to buy]] the colony of [[Louisiana (New France)|La Louisiane]] from the [[French First Republic|French Republic]] for the price of [[USD|$]]15 million. |- |Dec 20||The United States officially takes control of [[Louisiana (New France)|Louisiana]], an enormous area of imprecise boundaries extending from the [[Mississippi River]] west to the [[Rocky Mountains]], more than doubling the land area of the new nation. |- |rowspan=1|1804||May 14||The [[Lewis and Clark expedition]] sets out to explore and chart the territory acquired in the [[Louisiana Purchase]]. Officially titled the Corps of Discovery, the party canoes up the [[Missouri River]] from [[St. Charles, Missouri|Saint Charles]], spending the winter at [[Fort Mandan]] on Indian territory in what is now [[North Dakota]].{{Cite web|year=1998|url=http://www.lewis-clark.org/content/content-article.asp?ArticleID=3018|title=The Lewis & Clark Expedition: A Western Adventure – A National Epic|accessdate=Sep 24, 2008}} |- |rowspan=1|1805||Nov 7||[[Lewis and Clark expedition|Lewis and Clark]] sight the Pacific Ocean for the first time, near the mouth of the [[Columbia River]]. The expedition winters at [[Fort Clatsop]] on the south side of the river, near present-day [[Astoria, Oregon]]. |- |rowspan=2|1806||Jul 15||A [[Pike expedition|U.S. Army reconnaissance expedition]] under the command of Lieutenant [[Zebulon Pike]] departs [[Fort Bellefontaine]] near [[St. Louis, Missouri|Saint Louis]] to explore the southern [[Louisiana Territory]]. |- |Sep 23||[[Lewis and Clark expedition|Lewis and Clark]] return to Saint Louis after a journey of nearly 6,000 total miles; in the past two and a half years, the party has made contact with over 70 Indian tribes and produced 140 maps, as well as documented more than 200 [[List of species described by the Lewis and Clark Expedition|new plant and animal species]].{{cite book |last='''Uldrich''' |first=Jack |title=Into the unknown: leadership lessons from Lewis & Clark's daring westward adventure |ref=Uldrich |year=2004 |publisher=AMACOM Div American Mgmt Assn. |pages=245 |isbn=0-8144-0816-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RRuKF35bPJ0C}} |- |rowspan=1|1807||Feb 26||[[Viceroyalty of New Spain|Spanish]] cavalrymen arrest the [[Pike expedition]] in the province of [[Santa Fe de Nuevo México]] (now southern [[Colorado]]). |- |rowspan=2|1808||Apr 6||German immigrant [[John Jacob Astor]] incorporates his [[American Fur Company]].{{cite book|last1=Emmerich|first1=Alexander|title=John Jacob Astor and the First Great American Fortune|date=2013|publisher=McFarland & Company, Inc., Publishers|location=Jefferson, North Carolina|isbn=978-0-7864-7213-0}} |- |Nov 10||The [[Treaty of Fort Clark]] is signed, in which the [[Osage Nation]] cedes all of its territory east of [[Fort Osage|Fort Clark]] and north of the [[Arkansas River]] to the United States.{{cite web|author1=Kappler, Charles J. (ed.)|title=TREATY WITH THE OSAGE, 1808.|url=http://digital.library.okstate.edu/Kappler/Vol2/treaties/osa0095.htm#mn6|website=Indian Affairs: Laws and Treaties - Volume II (Treaties, 1778-1883)|publisher=Oklahoma State University Library|accessdate=4 September 2017|date=1904}} |} {{clear}} ==1810s== [[File:Vue de l’etablissement russe de la Bodega, à la Côte de la Nouvelle Albion, en 1828.jpg|thumb|A view of [[Fort Ross]] in 1828 by A.B. Duhaut-Cilly]] [[File:Stephen Harriman Long portrait montage.jpg|thumb|[[Stephen Harriman Long]]]] {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=1|1810||Sep 16||Mexican priest [[Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla]] [[Grito de Dolores|proclaims]] the independence of [[Mexico]] from the [[Joseph-Napoléon Bonaparte|Kingdom of Spain]]. |- |rowspan=2|1811||May||[[Fort Astoria]] is established by [[John Jacob Astor]]'s [[Pacific Fur Company]] at the mouth of the [[Columbia River]]. It is the first American settlement on the Pacific coast. |- |Jun 15–16||Most of the crew of the ''[[Tonquin (1807)|Tonquin]]'', one of Astor's ships trading on [[Vancouver Island]], is [[Battle of Woody Point|massacred]] by [[Tla-o-qui-aht First Nations|Tla-o-qui-aht]] Indians after the captain insults a chief. The ship is [[scuttling|scuttled]] the following day in a [[magazine (artillery)|magazine]] explosion that kills at least 100 natives.Franchère, Gabriel (1851). "Narrative of a voyage to the Northwest coast of America, in the years 1811, 1812, 1813, and 1814, or, The first American settlement on the Pacific". Retrieved 2017-09-05. |- |rowspan=4|1812||Mar||[[Fort Ross]] is established by [[Russian Empire|Russian]] traders on the [[California]] coast as the hub of the southernmost colony in [[Russian America]].{{cite book |title=History of Alaska: 1730–1885 |author1=Hubert Howe Bancroft |author2=Alfred Bates |author3=Ivan Petroff |author4=William Nemos |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HQQTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA482&lpg=PA482&dq=kuskof+bodega&source=bl&ots=32JOEFWJ3B&sig=E8NTuHcP2MqQGkbmgZ_DWQraFBM&hl=en&ei=KnRJS9LHMIbwsgPlt9n1Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CBIQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=rumiantzof&f=false |page=482 |year=1887 |publisher=A. L. Bancroft & company |location=San Francisco, California |accessdate=Jan 10, 2010}} |- |Apr 30||[[Louisiana]] is admitted as the [[List of U.S. states by date of admission to the Union|18th U.S. state]], and the first to include land west of the Mississippi River. It is also the first state organized from the [[Louisiana Territory|Louisiana Purchase territory]], the rest of which is soon renamed the [[Missouri Territory]]. |- |Sep 4||Scottish and Irish settlers led by [[Miles Macdonell]] formally take possession of the [[Red River Colony]]. They construct Fort Daer near present-day [[Pembina, North Dakota]], which becomes the first permanent European-American settlement in the Dakotas.{{cite journal|last1=Henderson|first1=Anne Matheson|title=The Lord Selkirk Settlement at Red River, Part 1|journal=Manitoba Pageant|date=Autumn 1967|volume=13|issue=1|url=http://www.mhs.mb.ca/docs/pageant/13/selkirksettlement1.shtml|accessdate=21 April 2018|publisher=Manitoba Historical Society}} |- |Oct 21||Carrying word of the fate of the ''Tonquin'' to [[St. Louis, Missouri|Saint Louis]], seven men of the Pacific Fur Company, led by [[Robert Stuart (explorer)|Robert Stuart]], become the first European Americans to cross the [[Continental Divide]] at [[South Pass (Wyoming)|South Pass]], in present-day [[Wyoming]]. Later in the century, the pass will be used by half a million westward migrants as part of the main route of several [[Westward Expansion Trails|emigrant trails]].Robert Stuart, Kenneth A. Spaulding (Ed.), ''On The Oregon Trail: Robert Stuart’s Journey of Discovery''. University of Oklahoma Press (1953). |- |rowspan=1|1813||Mar 29||During the [[Mexican War of Independence]], a [[Gutiérrez–Magee Expedition|joint expedition]] of Mexican and American [[filibuster (military)|filibusters]] penetrates deep into [[Spanish Texas]] and defeats a Royalist army outside [[San Antonio de Béxar]] at the [[Battle of Rosillo Creek]]. Provincial governor [[Manuel María de Salcedo]] is executed five days later.Walker, Henry P. (1962–1963) ''William McLane's narrative of the Magee-Gutierrez expedition, 1812-1813''. Austin, TX: Texas State Historical Association. {{OCLC|30688594}}. |- |rowspan=1|1817||Dec 25||Construction begins on a frontier military post known as [[Fort Smith, Arkansas|Fort Smith]] in what is now [[Arkansas]].{{cite web|title=Chronology of Fort Smith|url=http://www.fortsmithhistory.org/archive/chronology.html|website=Fort Smith Historical Society Inc.|accessdate=24 September 2017}} |- |rowspan=1|1818||Oct 20||The [[Treaty of 1818]] establishes the [[49th parallel north|49th parallel]] from [[Lake of the Woods]] west to the Rocky Mountains as the boundary between the United States and [[British North America]].{{cite web|last=LexUM |year=2000 |url=http://www.lexum.umontreal.ca/ca_us/en/cus.1818.15.en.html |title=Convention of Commerce between His Majesty and the United States of America.--Signed at London, 20th October, 1818 |work=Canado-American Treaties |publisher=University of Montreal |accessdate=2006-03-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050106120753/http://www.lexum.umontreal.ca/ca_us/en/cus.1818.15.en.html |archivedate=January 6, 2005 }} |- |rowspan=2|1819||Mar 2||The [[Arkansas Territory]] is organized. |- ||Sep 17||Intending to build forts along the [[Missouri River]], [[Yellowstone expedition|a U.S. Army expedition]] led by Colonel [[Henry Atkinson (soldier)|Henry Atkinson]] and Major [[Stephen Harriman Long]] arrives by [[paddle steamer]] at [[Fort Calhoun, Nebraska|Council Bluff]] on the river's west bank, in present-day [[Nebraska]]. It establishes what later becomes [[Fort Atkinson (Nebraska)|Fort Atkinson]], the first Army outpost in the region, but the expedition stalls there over the winter and collapses entirely in the spring.{{cite book|last=Chittenden|first=Hiram Martin|year=1902|title=The American Fur Trade of the Far West: A History of the Pioneer Trading Posts and Early Fur Companies of the Missouri Valley and the Rocky Mountains and of the Overland Commerce with Santa Fe (Vol. II)|chapter=Chapter II: The Yellowstone Expedition of 1819-1820|pages=562–587|publisher=Francis P. Harper|location=New York|doi=10.14288/1.0226338}} |} {{clear}} ==1820s== [[File:Prairie dog titian ramsay peale.jpg|thumb|''Prairie dog'' by [[Titian Ramsay Peale]], c. 1819–1821]] [[File:James Beckwourth.jpg|thumb|[[Jim Beckwourth]]]] {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=2|1820||Mar 5||Congress passes the [[Missouri Compromise]], prohibiting slavery in the unorganized territory north of [[parallel 36°30′ north|36.5° latitude]] and west of the [[Mississippi River]], except within the boundaries of the proposed state of [[Missouri]], while permitting the admission of [[Maine]] as a [[slave and free states|free state]]. Largely devised by [[Henry Clay]], it is a landmark agreement in the debate over slavery in the West. |- |May||Major [[Stephen H. Long]] leads a scientific expedition up the [[Platte River]], along the [[Front Range]] of the Rocky Mountains, south to the [[Arkansas River|Arkansas]] and [[Canadian River|Canadian]] rivers, and finally east to present-day [[Fort Smith, Arkansas]]. Among the first expeditions to bring American artists and scientists into the West, the party includes painter Samuel Seymour, artist-naturalist [[Titian Peale]], and physician [[Edwin James (scientist)|Edwin James]], who leads the first recorded ascent of [[Pikes Peak]]. Long's report, published in 1823, promotes the idea of the [[Great Plains]] as the "[[Great American Desert]]".{{cite book|last1=Rhonda|first1=James P.|editor1-last=Deverell|editor1-first=William|editor1-link=William Deverell (historian)|title=A Companion to the American West|date=2004|publisher=Blackwell Publishing|location=Malden, MA|isbn=0-631-21357-0|pages=65–68|chapter=Passion and Imagination in the Exploration of the American West}}{{cite web|title=Scientific Expedition of Major Stephen H. Long|url=http://www.kansasgenealogy.com/history/scientific_expedition.htm|website=Kansas Genealogy|accessdate=6 October 2015}} |- |rowspan=4|1821||Feb 22||The [[Adams–Onís Treaty]] takes effect exactly two years after its initial signing, defining a new border between the territory of [[New Spain]] and the United States and further securing American claims to the Louisiana Purchase and the [[Oregon Country]].{{cite book|last1=Milner|first1=Clyde A., II|editor1-last=Milner|editor1-first=Clyde A., II|editor2-last=O'Connor|editor2-first=Carol A.|editor3-last=Sandweiss|editor3-first=Martha A.|title=The Oxford history of the American West|date=1994|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=0-19-511212-1|page=158|chapter=National Initiatives}} |- |Aug 10||[[Missouri]] is admitted as the 24th U.S. state. |- |Aug 24||The [[Ferdinand VII of Spain|Kingdom of Spain]] finally recognizes the independence of [[Mexico]] with the signing of the [[Treaty of Córdoba]], ending the [[Mexican War of Independence]]. |- |Sep 1||[[William Becknell]] and a party of frontier traders leave [[New Franklin, Missouri]] bound for [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]]. The Becknell route will become the [[Santa Fe Trail]]. |- |rowspan=1|1822||Mar 6||[[William Henry Ashley]] and [[Andrew Henry (fur trader)|Andrew Henry]] place an advertisement in the ''Missouri Republican'' for one hundred "enterprising young men" to join a [[North American fur trade|trapping]] expedition to the upper [[Missouri River]]. The respondents comprise "[[Rocky Mountain Fur Company|Ashley's Hundred]]", many of whom, along with those that join in the following years, earn reputations as famous explorers and [[mountain man|mountain men]]. These men include [[Jedediah Smith]], [[Jim Bridger]], [[Hugh Glass]], and [[Jim Beckwourth]].[http://www.americanantiquarian.org/proceedings/44807104.pdf "Notes on General Ashley, the Overland Trail, and South Pass"] ''Proceedings of the American Antiquarian Society'' '''54'''(2): 161–312. 1944 |- |rowspan=3|1824||Apr 17||The [[Russo-American Treaty of 1824]] is signed, formally transferring [[Russian Empire|Russian]] claims in the Pacific Northwest south of [[parallel 54°40′ north|54°40′ N latitude]] to the United States.[http://www.explorenorth.com/library/history/bl-rusus1825.htm Text of Russo-American Treaty of 1824] |- |Apr 21||[[Fort Gibson]] is established near the confluence of the [[Grand River (Oklahoma)|Grand River]] and the [[Arkansas River]] in present-day [[Oklahoma]].[http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/F/FO033.html Brad Agnew, "Fort Gibson"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027183858/http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/F/FO033.html |date=2014-10-27 }}, ''Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture''. |- |Jul 7||The first of 297 pioneer families and partnerships known as the "[[Old Three Hundred]]" are granted [[land title]]s in [[Stephen F. Austin]]'s empresarial colony in [[Coahuila y Tejas]]. They are the first American settlers of [[Mexican Texas]] under a recently reformed Mexican law.Bugbee, Lester G. “The Old Three Hundred: A List of Settlers in Austin's First Colony.” ''The Quarterly of the Texas State Historical Association'', Vol. 1, No. 2, 1897, pp. 108–117. JSTOR, https://www.jstor.org/stable/30242636?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents |- |rowspan=2|1827||Mar 29||The town of [[Independence, Missouri]] is founded. In later years it becomes a common point of departure for pioneers journeying west on the [[emigrant trail]]s.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RfAuAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA177#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=How Missouri Counties, Towns and Streams Were Named | publisher=The State Historical Society of Missouri | author=Eaton, David Wolfe | year=1916 | pages=177}} |- |May 8||Colonel [[Henry Leavenworth]] founds a U.S. Army cantonment later known as [[Fort Leavenworth]] above the confluence of the [[Little Platte River|Little Platte]] and the Missouri River in present-day [[Kansas]].[http://www-cgsc.army.mil/carl/resources/ftlvn/briefhist/briefhist.asp#inhabitants A Brief History of Fort Leavenworth – John W. Partin] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080320124049/http://www-cgsc.army.mil/carl/resources/ftlvn/briefhist/briefhist.asp#inhabitants |date=2008-03-20 }}. |- |rowspan=1|1828||Jul 14||Trapper, explorer, and mountain man [[Jedediah Smith]] and his party are attacked by [[Umpqua people|Umpqua]] Indians in Oregon Country. Smith and three others are the only survivors. |- |rowspan=1|1829||Nov 7||A merchant caravan led by [[Antonio Armijo]] embarks from [[Abiquiú, New Mexico]] and successfully reaches [[Mission San Gabriel Arcángel|San Gabriel, California]] 86 days later, becoming the first to travel the length of the [[Old Spanish Trail (trade route)|Old Spanish Trail]].{{cite web |url=http://www.oldspanishtrail.org/learn/trail_history.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-04-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421211849/http://www.oldspanishtrail.org/learn/trail_history.php |archivedate=2016-04-21 |df= }} |} {{clear}} ==1830s== [[File:Benjamin Louis Eulalie de Bonneville.jpg|thumb|[[Benjamin Bonneville|Benjamin Louis Eulalie de Bonneville]]]] [[File:Thomas Flintoff - Sam Houston - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|[[Sam Houston]]]] {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=2|1830||Apr 6||The [[Law of April 6, 1830]] is passed by the [[First Mexican Republic|Mexican government]], which increases tariffs on American goods entering Mexico, cancels unfulfilled colonization contracts, and bans any further immigration from the United States to [[Mexican Texas]].{{citation|title=Myths, Misdeeds, and Misunderstandings: The Roots of Conflict in U.S.–Mexican Relations|editor-last=Rodriguez O.|editor-first=Jaime E.|editor2-last=Vincent|editor2-first=Kathryn|location=[[Wilmington, DE]]|year=1997|publisher=Scholarly Resources Inc.|isbn=0-8420-2662-2|contribution=The Colonization and Loss of Texas: A Mexican Perspective|last=Vázquez|first=Josefina Zoraida|authorlink=Josefina Zoraida Vázquez}} |- |May 28||The [[Indian Removal Act]] is signed into law by President [[Andrew Jackson]], authorizing the U.S. government to negotiate the [[Indian removal|removal]] of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] tribes of the southeastern United States to [[Indian Territory|federal territory]] in what is now [[Oklahoma]]. |- |rowspan=1|1831|| ||[[Mexico]] ratifies the boundaries with the United States originally established by the [[Adams–Onís Treaty]]. |- |rowspan=3|1832||May||The [[Bonneville Expedition of 1832|Bonneville Expedition]] departs Missouri with 110 men. The Crabb Massacre|author=Thomas Edwin Farish|publisher=|accessdate=11 December 2014}} |- |Sep 11||Nearly 120 emigrants passing through the [[Utah Territory]] are [[Mountain Meadows massacre|massacred]] by a combined force of [[Mormon]] militiamen and [[Southern Paiute|Paiute]] Indians during the hysteria of the [[Utah War]]. |- |rowspan=4|1858||Feb 19||[[Chief Leschi]], a leader of the [[Nisqually people]], is [[hanging|hanged]] by the territorial government of Washington after being wrongfully convicted of killing a colonel during the [[Puget Sound War]].{{cite book |last=Meeker |first=Ezra |authorlink=Ezra Meeker |title=Pioneer Reminiscences of Puget Sound, the Tragedy of Leschi |year=1905 |url=http://ebooks.library.ualberta.ca/local/pioneerreminisce00meekuoft |oclc=667877082 |location=Seattle, WA |publisher=Lowman & Hanford Stationery and Print. Co}} |- |May 11||[[Minnesota]] is admitted as the 32nd U.S. state. |- |May 12||An army of [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Rangers]] and Indian allies under the command of [[John Salmon Ford]] engages [[Comanche]] warriors in [[Battle of Little Robe Creek|a series of battles]] after attacking villages in the [[Canadian River]] valley, the final actions of the [[Antelope Hills expedition]].[[T. R. Fehrenbach|Fehrenbach, Theodore Reed]] ''The Comanches: The Destruction of a People''. New York: Knopf, 1974. {{ISBN|0-394-48856-3}}. |- |Jul||[[Gold mining in Colorado|Gold]] is discovered in the [[Front Range]] of the Rocky Mountains. The [[Pike's Peak Gold Rush|resulting gold rush]] draws nearly 100,000 people to the [[Pike's Peak Country]] of present-day Colorado over the next three years.{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Robert|title=The Great Pikes Peak Gold Rush|year=1985|publisher=Caxton Press|location=Caldwell, Idaho|isbn=0-87004-412-5}} |- |rowspan=3|1859||Spring||The [[Comstock Lode]], the first major discovery of [[silver]] ore in the country, provokes a [[silver rush]] in present-day [[Nevada]] that funds [[boomtown]]s including [[Virginia City, Nevada|Virginia City]] and [[Gold Hill, Nevada|Gold Hill]]. Over the next 30 years, hundreds of mines extract more than $320 million in gold and silver from the region, making millionaires of investors such as [[George Hearst]] and the [[Bonanza Kings]].Smith, G.H., 1943, The History of the Comstock Lode, 1850–1997, Reno: University of Nevada Press, {{ISBN|1888035048}} |- |Feb 14||[[Oregon]] is admitted as the 33rd U.S. state. |- |Sep 28–30||Mexican folk hero [[Juan Cortina]] and a large posse seize control of [[Brownsville, Texas]] in one of the major actions of the First Cortina War. His motivation is the legal abuses perpetrated by Texan authorities against ethnic Mexicans. The occupation only lasts two days, but the [[Cortina Troubles]] continue for another two years.{{cite book|last=Elman|first=Robert|title=Badmen of the West|publisher=Ridge Press|series=|year=1974|doi=|isbn=0-600-31353-0}} |} {{clear}} ==1860s== [[File:Henry Hopkins Sibley.jpg|thumb|[[Henry Hopkins Sibley]]]] [[File:JohnBozeman.JPG|thumb|[[John Bozeman]]]] [[File:Bloody-bill-anderson.jpg|thumb|[[William T. Adamson Hoebel (1952). ''The Comanches: Lords of the Southern Plains''. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press. |- |rowspan=10|1861||Jan 29||[[Kansas]] is admitted to the Union as the 34th U.S. state, and a [[slave and free states|free state]]. |- |Feb||[[Bascom Affair|A series of hostilities]] involving U.S. Army Lt. [[George Nicholas Bascom]] and [[Chiricahua]] [[Apache]] chief [[Cochise]] triggers the [[Apache Wars|Chiricahua Wars]], which remain a central conflict in [[Arizona]] and [[New Mexico]] for the next 25 years. |- |Feb 1||A convention of the [[Texas in the American Civil War|Texas]] legislature votes to [[secession|secede]] from the Union.{{cite web |title=An Ordinance: To dissolve the union between the State of Texas and the other States, united under the compact styled "The Constitution of the United States of America." Baylor]] engage Union forces under Isaac Lynde at [[Mesilla, New Mexico]], resulting in Lynde's troops retreating into the [[Organ Mountains]], toward [[Fort Stanton]]. Lynde is relieved of duty after abandoning his post. |- |Sep 2||A small Confederate patrol from Fort Stanton is [[Gallinas massacre|ambushed]] by [[Mescalero]] [[Apache]] warriors in New Mexico's [[Gallinas Mountains]].{{cite book|last=Josephy|first=Alvin M. Jr.|title=War on the Frontier: The Trans-Mississippi West|year=1986|publisher=Time-Life Books|location=Alexandria, VA|isbn=0-8094-4780-0}} |- |Oct 24||The [[first transcontinental telegraph]] line is completed near [[Fort Bridger]] in present-day [[Wyoming]], the result of an effort by [[Hiram Sibley]] and [[Western Union]] to connect California to the telegraph networks of the east. The ability to instantaneously send messages from coast to coast immediately makes the [[Pony Express]] obsolete.{{cite web |url=http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Milestones:Transcontinental_Telegraph,_1861 |title=Milestones:Transcontinental Telegraph, 1861 |author= |date= |work=IEEE Global History Network |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=27 July 2011}} |- |rowspan=13|1862||Winter||Months of record precipitation in the far west culminate in the [[Great Flood of 1862]], which turns California's [[Central Valley (California)|Central Valley]] into an inland sea and causes millions of dollars in property damage.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/calbk:@field(DOCID+@lit(calbk142div21)): William H. Brewer, ''Up and down California in 1860–1864'', New Haven, Yale University Press, 1930, p. 243] Retrieved 23 October 2010.{{cite journal |url=http://www.vetmed.wsu.edu/org_NWS/NWSci%20journal%20articles/1940-1949/1947%20vol%2021/21-2/v21%20p76%20Wells.PDF |journal=Northwest Science |volume=21 |year=1947 |last=Lansing Wells |first=Edward |title=Notes on the Winter of 1861–2 in the Pacific Northwest |pages=76–83 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610144529/http://www.vetmed.wsu.edu/org_NWS/NWSci%20journal%20articles/1940-1949/1947%20vol%2021/21-2/v21%20p76%20Wells.PDF |archivedate=2011-06-10 |df= }} |- |Feb–Apr||Confederate forces under Brigadier General [[Henry Hopkins Sibley]] and Colonel [[Thomas Green (general)|Thomas Green]] undertake one of the most ambitious military operations of the [[American Civil War]] when they begin the [[New Mexico Campaign]]. Their goals include seizing the Colorado gold fields and securing roads by which to invade California and Mexico. |- |Feb 20–21||The [[Battle of Valverde]] is fought at a ford of Valverde Creek in present-day New Mexico, resulting in a Confederate victory. |- |Mar 26–28||The [[Battle of Glorieta Pass]] is fought in the [[Sangre de Cristo Mountains]] between Confederate cavalry forces and Union volunteers from [[Colorado in the American Civil War|Colorado]] and [[New Mexico in the American Civil War|New Mexico]]. It marks a turning point in the [[New Mexico Campaign]] in favor of the Union. |- |Mar 30||The [[Battle of Stanwix Station]] is fought at a [[Butterfield Overland Mail]] [[stagecoach]] stop 80 miles east of [[Yuma, Arizona]] between Capt. William P. Calloway of the [[California Column]] and Confederate 2nd Lt. [[Jack Swilling]]. |- |Apr 15||The [[Battle of Picacho Pass]] is fought between the [[1st California Cavalry]] under Union Lt. [[James Barrett (Civil War)|James Barrett]] and a detachment of Arizona Confederates led by Sgt. Henry Holmes. It is often cited as the westernmost battle of the [[American Civil War]], occurring 50 miles northwest of [[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson]]. |- |May 5||Confederate Sgt. Sam Ford and his men are ambushed by [[Apache]] warriors led by [[Cochise]] in the [[Dragoon Mountains]], near present-day [[Benson, Arizona]], at the [[First Battle of Dragoon Springs]]. |- |May 9||The [[Second Battle of Dragoon Springs]] is fought in retaliation for the deaths of the four Confederates killed at the Apache ambush four days earlier. Rebels under Capt. [[Sherod Hunter]] take back the cattle stolen by [[Cochise]] and his warriors and kill five Apaches. |- |May 20||The [[Homestead Acts|Homestead Act of 1862]] is signed into law by President [[Abraham Lincoln]]. It aims to encourage settlement in the West by simplifying the process of land acquisition: [[homestead principle|homesteader]]s need only claim, occupy for five years, and improve a minimum of 160 acres of unappropriated land to be granted full ownership. Alternatively, settlers have the option of purchasing the land outright after six months of residency.{{cite web|title=The Homestead Act of 1862|url=https://www.archives.gov/education/lessons/homestead-act|website=National Archives|publisher=The U.S. National Archives and Records Administration|accessdate=6 January 2017}} |- |Jul 15–16||140 Union troops from the [[California Column]] are ambushed by 500 Apaches under [[Mangas Coloradas]] and [[Cochise]] at the [[Battle of Apache Pass]] in Arizona's [[Chiricahua Mountains]]. It is one of the first battles in which the [[United States Army]] is able to effectively use artillery against Indians. [[Fort Bowie]] is built near the site following the battle. |- |Aug 10||More than 30 people are killed when a group of Unionist [[German Texan]] settlers fleeing the [[Texas Hill Country]] for Mexico is [[Nueces massacre|attacked]] by a Confederate detachment along the [[Nueces River]].{{cite book|last=Marten|first=James|title=Texas Divided: Loyalty and Dissent in the Lone Star State, 1856-1874|year=1990|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|location=Lexington, Kentucky|ref=harv}} |- |Aug 17||The [[Dakota War of 1862]] begins when a [[Sioux]] hunting party slaughters five white settlers and the tribal council decides to attack white settlements throughout the [[Minnesota River]] valley. |- |Nov 5||More than 300 [[Santee Sioux]] in [[Minnesota]] are sentenced to hang for the rape and murder of white settlers. |- |rowspan=7|1863||Jan 1||[[Daniel Freeman (homesteader)|Daniel Freeman]] submits the first claim under the [[Homestead Acts#Homestead Act of 1862|Homestead Act of 1862]] for land near [[Beatrice, Nebraska]]. |- |Jan 18||[[Chiricahua]] [[Apache]] leader [[Mangas Coloradas]] is captured, tortured, and killed by U.S. Army sentries after meeting with Brigadier General [[Joseph Rodman West]] to call for peace. |- |Jan 29||Colonel [[Patrick Edward Connor]] leads his troops to fight [[Shoshone]] Indians in present-day Idaho, resulting in the [[Bear River Massacre]]. |- |Feb 24||The [[Arizona Territory]] is organized from a portion of the [[New Mexico Territory]]. |- |Mar 4||[[Idaho Territory|Idaho]] is organized as a U.S. territory. |- |Aug 21||[[Quantrill's Raiders|Confederate guerrillas]] led by [[William Quantrill]] set fire to the pro-Union town of [[Lawrence, Kansas]] and kill nearly 200 civilians in the [[Lawrence massacre]]. Quantrill claims his motive was revenge for the [[Sacking of Osceola]] several years earlier. |- |Aug 25||In the aftermath of the Lawrence massacre, Union General [[Thomas Ewing Jr.]] issues [[General Order No. 11 (1863)|General Order No. 11]], which forces the expulsion of all residents who cannot prove their allegiance to the Union from four counties in rural western [[Missouri in the American Civil War|Missouri]].{{cite book|last1=Eakin|first1=Joanne Chiles|title=Tears and Turmoil: Order No. 11|date=1996|location=Independence, Missouri}} |- |rowspan=9|1864|| ||[[John Bozeman]] leads a group of about 2,000 settlers along the [[Bozeman Trail]], a new cutoff route connecting the [[Oregon Trail]] with the gold fields of southwestern [[Montana Territory|Montana]], which he and John Jacobs had [[trail blazing|blazed]] the previous year. |- |Jan||Colonel [[Kit Carson]] accepts the surrender of most of the [[Navajo people|Navajo]] nation after the final two years of the bloody [[Navajo Wars]]. |- |May 26||[[Montana Territory|Montana]] is organized as a U.S. territory. |- |Jul||Outlaw Jim Reynolds and his gang plunder and rob settlements in the [[South Park (Park County, Colorado)|South Park Basin]] of the Colorado Territory in an attempt to loot the gold mines of the region to support the fledgling [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]]. |- |Sep 27||Pro-Confederate [[bushwhacker]]s led by [[William T. Anderson|William "Bloody Bill" Anderson]] capture and [[Centralia Massacre (Missouri)|execute]] 24 unarmed Union soldiers at a rail depot in [[Centralia, Missouri]]. |- |Oct 23||Union General [[Samuel R. Curtis]]' [[Army of the Border]] decisively defeats Confederate General [[Sterling Price]]'s [[Army of Missouri]] at the [[Battle of Westport]], near [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]]. The battle ends the [[Price's Raid|last major Confederate offensive]] west of the Mississippi River. The largest engagement in the [[Trans-Mississippi Theater of the American Civil War|Trans-Mississippi Theater]], with over 30,000 men involved, it is sometimes called the "Gettysburg of the West".Castel, Albert E. ''General Sterling Price and the Civil War in the West''. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1993. {{ISBN|0-8071-1854-0}}. |- |Oct 25||In consecutive engagements only hours apart, Union cavalry under [[Alfred Pleasonton]] pursue and defeat Confederate forces under Sterling Price at [[Battle of Marais des Cygnes|Marais des Cygnes]], [[Battle of Mine Creek|Mine Creek]], and [[Battle of Marmiton River|Marmiton River]] as they retreat through [[Kansas in the American Civil War|Kansas]] and [[Missouri in the American Civil War|Missouri]]. |- |Oct 31||[[Nevada]] is admitted as the 36th U.S. state. |- |Nov 29||Colonel [[John Chivington]] and his volunteer militia massacre a peaceful [[Cheyenne]] village near Sand Creek in the [[Colorado Territory]], in what is later called the [[Sand Creek massacre]]. |- |rowspan=4|1865||Feb 17||[[Fort Buchanan, Arizona|Fort Buchanan]] is overrun and destroyed by [[Chiricahua]] warriors in the Arizona Territory.{{cite book |last=Scott |first=N. Davis |title=The war of the rebellion: a compilation of the official records of the Union and Confederate armies |year=1897 |publisher=United States Government Printing Office |location=Washington D.C. |pages=401–403}} |- |May 12–13||The [[Battle of Palmito Ranch]] is fought near [[Brownsville, Texas]]. It is the final armed engagement of the [[American Civil War]]. |- |Jun 23||[[Stand Watie]], a [[Cherokee Nation (1794–1907)|Cherokee]] [[Indian cavalry|cavalry]] commander in the [[Confederate States Army|Confederate Army]], becomes the last Confederate general to surrender to Union forces, at [[Doaksville]] in the [[Indian Territory in the American Civil War|Indian Territory]].{{cite web|last=Franks|first=Kenny A|title=Watie's Regiment|work=Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture|url=http://www.okhistory.org/publications/enc/entry.php?entryname=WATIE%27S%20REGIMENT|accessdate=December 22, 2012}} |- |Jul 21||[[Wild Bill Hickok|"Wild Bill" Hickok]] kills gambler [[Davis Tutt]] in [[Wild Bill Hickok-Davis Tutt shootout|a shootout]] in [[Springfield, Missouri]]. It is often considered the archetypal one-on-one [[fast draw|quick-draw duel]], which later becomes a popular image of the Old West.{{cite book|last=Connelley|first=William E.|title=Wild Bill and His Era: The Life and Adventures of James Butler Hickok|year=1933|pages=84–5}} |- |rowspan=3|1866||Feb 13||Ex-Confederate bushwhackers [[Frank James|Frank]] and [[Jesse James]] rob their first bank, the Clay County Savings Association in [[Liberty, Missouri]]. |- |Spring||The [[Cattle drives in the United States|period of the great cattle drives]] begins when [[Texas]] ranchers drive more than 260,000 head of cattle to assorted markets. Some travel east to Louisiana, where the animals are shipped to [[Cairo, Illinois]] and [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]]; others travel west to [[Fort Sumner, New Mexico]] and [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]], inaugurating the [[Goodnight-Loving Trail]]. But the vast majority follow the [[Texas Road|Shawnee Trail]] north to [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] or [[Sedalia, Missouri]].[http://genealogytrails.com/tex/state/cattledrives.html "The History of Cattle Drives"] on the [http://genealogytrails.com/ ''Genealogy Trails''] website |- |Dec 21||Captain [[William J. Fetterman]] and 80 soldiers of the U.S. 2nd Cavalry and 18th Infantry regiments are [[Fetterman Fight|ambushed and wiped out]] by [[Lakota people|Lakota]], [[Cheyenne]], and [[Arapaho]] warriors near [[Fort Phil Kearny]], [[Wyoming]]. Smith of [[Kent, Ohio]] is issued the first patent for [[barbed wire]] fencing, an invention which revolutionizes [[cattle ranching]] on the open prairies of the West.{{cite web|url=http://www.ohiohistorycentral.org/entry.php?rec=2672|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071003100907/http://www.ohiohistorycentral.org/entry.php?rec=2672|archivedate=2007-10-03|title=Lucien B. Smith|accessdate=2009-01-28|work=Ohio History Central|publisher=Ohio Historical Society|date=31 July 2006}} |- |Aug 2||In the [[Wagon Box Fight]], a small party of U.S. Army soldiers and civilians near Fort Phil Kearny, armed with new rapid-fire [[breech-loading]] rifles and encircled by a wall of wagon boxes, manages to hold off hundreds of Lakota warriors led by [[Red Cloud]] and [[Crazy Horse]].Keenan, Jerry. ''The Wagon Box Fight''. Boulder, CO: Lightning Tree Press, 1990, p. 22. |- |Oct 21–28||The [[Medicine Lodge Treaty]] is signed between the U.S. government and several southern [[Plains Indians|Plains Indian]] tribes, requiring that the tribes relocate to the [[Indian Territory]]."Treaty with the Kiowa and Comanche, 1867" (Medicine Lodge Treaty), 15 Stats. 581, Oct. 21, 1867."Treaty with the Kiowa, Comanche, and Apache, 1867" (Medicine Lodge Treaty), 15 Stats. 589, Oct. 21, 1867."Treaty with the Cheyenne and Arapaho, 1867" (Medicine Lodge Treaty), 15 Stats. 593, Oct. 28, 1867. |- |rowspan=3|1868||Apr 29||The [[Treaty of Fort Laramie (1868)]] is signed between the United States and several bands of [[Lakota people|Lakota]], [[Dakota people|Dakota]], and [[Arapaho]] Indians. (retrieved 19 Dec 2010) |- |Jul 25||[[Wyoming Territory|Wyoming]] is organized as a U.S. territory.{{cite web|date=July 25, 1868|url=http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=015/llsl015.db&recNum=211|title=An Act to provide a temporary Government for the Territory of Wyoming|format=cgi-bin|author=[[Fortieth United States Congress]]|accessdate=June 5, 2009}} |- |Nov 27||The [[Battle of Washita River]] is fought when Lt. Col. [[George Armstrong Custer]]'s [[7th Cavalry Regiment]] attacks a winter encampment of [[Cheyenne|Southern Cheyenne]] Indians on the [[Washita River]] in what is now western [[Oklahoma]]. Chief [[Black Kettle]], leader of the Cheyenne, is killed. |- |rowspan=5|1869||Jan 8||[[Fort Sill]] is established by General [[Philip H. Sheridan]] in the [[Indian Territory]], near present-day [[Lawton, Oklahoma]]. |- |May 10||[[Leland Stanford]] drives the [[Golden Spike]] to join the rails of the [[Central Pacific Railroad|Central Pacific]] and [[Union Pacific Railroad|Union Pacific]] railroads at a special ceremony in [[Promontory Summit, Utah|Promontory Summit, Utah Territory]], completing the [[First Transcontinental Railroad]]. |- |May 24||[[John Wesley Powell]] and nine others embark on [[Powell Geographic Expedition of 1869|a scientific expedition]] that charts more than 930 miles of the [[Green River (Colorado River)|Green River]] and [[Colorado River]] through the canyon country of [[Wyoming Territory|Wyoming]], [[Colorado Territory|Colorado]], [[Utah Territory|Utah]], and [[Arizona Territory|Arizona]]. Powell and his crew become the first recorded white men to travel the length of the [[Grand Canyon]]. They reach the mouth of the [[Virgin River]] in present-day [[Nevada]] on August 30. |- |Jul 4||The world's first documented competitive [[rodeo]] is held in the town of [[Deer Trail, Colorado|Deer Trail]] in the [[Colorado Territory]].{{cite news |author= |title=Wrangling Over Where Rodeo Began |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/18/travel/wrangling-over-where-rodeo-began.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=June 18, 1989 |accessdate=2013-11-15 }} |- |Dec 10||[[Wyoming Territory|Wyoming]] becomes the first U.S. territory to grant women the [[suffrage|right to vote]]. |} {{clear}} ==1870s== [[File:Chief Ouray - Brady-Handy.jpg|thumb|[[Chief Ouray|Ouray]] and [[Chipeta]]]] [[File:Jesse and Frank James.gif|thumb|[[Jesse James|Jesse]] and [[Frank James]]]] [[File:Wild Bill Hickok sepia.png|thumb|[[Wild Bill Hickok|"Wild Bill" Hickok]]]] [[File:Cody-Buffalo-Bill-LOC.jpg|thumb|[[Bill Cody|"Buffalo Bill" Cody]]]] [[File:En-chief-sitting-bull.jpg|thumb|[[Sitting Bull|''Tȟatȟáŋka Íyotȟake'' (Sitting Bull)]]]] [[File:Custer Portrait Restored.jpg|thumb|[[George Armstrong Custer]]]] [[File:Calamity jane.jpeg|thumb|"[[Calamity Jane]]"]] [[File:Lewis Wallace.jpg|thumb|[[Lew Wallace]]]] {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=10|1870|| ||[[Bret Harte]]'s ''The Luck of Roaring Camp and Other Sketches'', a collection of stories based on his years as a San Francisco journalist, is published. |- | ||William "Hurricane Bill" Martin, a notorious outlaw in [[Kansas]], begins [[cattle rustling|rustling cattle]] southeast of [[Abilene, Kansas|Abilene]] before he and his gang are driven off by a posse from [[Marion, Kansas|Marion]].Rosa, Joseph G. ''Gunfighter: Man Or Myth?''. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 1969. (pg. 47) |- | ||Settling in the [[New Mexico Territory]], gunfighter [[Robert Clay Allison]] purchases a ranch in [[Colfax County, New Mexico|Colfax County]]. According to local newspapers, Allison is reported to have killed as many as fifteen men in gunfights during this time.Wexler, Bruce. ''The Wild, Wild West Of Louis L'amour: The Illustrated Guide to Cowboys, Indians, Gunslingers, Outlaws and Texas Rangers''. Philadelphia: Running Press, 2005. (pg. 78) {{ISBN|0-7624-2357-9}} |- | ||With the growing railroad industry and cattle boom, [[American bison|buffalo]] hunters begin moving onto the [[Great Plains]]. Over the next several decades, this provides Mormons with an added margin of political power. |- |Jan||Shortly after leaving the post of sheriff of [[Ellis County, Kansas]], [[Wild Bill Hickok|"Wild Bill" Hickok]] travels to [[Missouri]] and eventually resumes his duties as a [[U.S. Marshal]].Rosa, Joseph G. ''Wild Bill Hickok, Gunfighter: An Account of Hickok's Gunfights''. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 2003. (pg. 17) {{ISBN|0-8061-3535-2}} |- |Jan 23||More than 200 men, women, and children belonging to a friendly band of [[Piegan Blackfeet]] Indians are mistakenly attacked and [[Marias Massacre|massacred]] by a U.S. Army command on the [[Marias River]] in the [[Montana Territory]].{{cite book |author=Hutton, Paul Andrew |title=Phil Sheridan and His Army |chapter=Forming Military Indian Policy: 'The Only Good Indian Is a Dead Indian' |pages=181–200 |year=1985 |isbn=0-8032-2329-3 |publisher=University of Nebraska Press |location=Lincoln, NE}} |- |Spring||With the emergence of [[Abilene, Kansas]] as a major stopover for cattle ranchers, the town trustees attempt to curb the violence brought by the beginning of the cattle season by banning guns within town limits. Smith|Tom "Bear River" Smith]] as city marshal on June 4.Rosa, Joseph G. ''Gunfighter: Man Or Myth?''. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 1969. (pg. 196) |- |Jul 17–18||[[Wild Bill Hickok|"Wild Bill" Hickok]] is involved in a shootout with several members of the [[7th Cavalry Regiment (United States)|U.S. 7th Cavalry Regiment]] in [[Hays, Kansas|Hays City]] after killing one trooper and wounding another. |- |Nov 2||Abilene City Marshal [[Thomas J. Smith|Tom "Bear River" Smith]] is killed while serving an arrest warrant near the town. |- |rowspan=11|1871|| ||[[King Fisher|John K. {{For|species with only one sex|Gonochorism}} '''Unisex''' refers to things that are not [[sex-specific]], being suitable for either [[sex]].<ref>[http://www.askoxford.com/concise_oed/unisex?view=uk obkaqfAskOxford: unisex<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/unisex unisex - Definitions from Dictionary.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It can also be another term for [[gender-blindness]].
The term was coined in the 1960s and was used fairly informally. Though the combining form ''uni-'' is from the Latin ''unus'' meaning ''one'', the term seems to have been influenced by words such as ''united'' and ''universal'' where the ''uni-'' prefix takes on the sense of ''shared''. In this sense, it can be seen as meaning ''shared by sexes''.<ref>[http://www.askoxford.com/asktheexperts/faq/aboutwords/unisex?view=uk AskOxford: Why does 'unisex' refer to something to do with various exes, not just one sex?<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Hair stylists and [[beauty salon]]s that serve both men and women are often referred to as unisex. This is also typical of other services and products that had traditionally been separated by sexes, such as clothing shops or beauty products. A facility that is usually [[sex segregated]] but is not so designated may be referred to as unisex, such as a [[public toilet]]. [[Unisex clothing]] includes garments like T-shirts; versions of other garments may be tailored for the different fits depending on one's [[sex]], such as jeans. The sharing of a pool, beach or other water or recreational facility by swimmers and others of various sexes is commonly referred to as [[mixed bathing]]. 'Mates' was the first unisex store created by Irvine Sellar in England. When a school admits students of various sexes, it may be called coeducational or a [[mixed-sex education|mixed-sex school]].
==See also== {{wiktionary|unisex}} *[[Coeducation]] *[[Mixed bathing]] *[[Unisex name]] *[[Unisex clothing]] *[[Gender-neutral toilet]] *[[Gender role]] *[[Gender mainstreaming]]

{{original research|date=July 2010}}
'''Virginity fraud''' (also known as '''chastity fraud,''' or the '''virginity lie''') is held to occur when someone lies about his or her [[virginity]] in order to obtain something of value. The concept is controversial, especially in view of fundamental societal disagreement over the definition and importance of virginity and [[gender role]]s (including the sexual [[double standard]]).
The archetypal case is of a woman who falsely claims to be a virgin for the sake of marriage to a man whom she suspects of insisting on, or at least valuing, virginity in his bride. (Other situations – such as two lovers who claimed to lose their virginity together on the internet as a [[publicity stunt]]<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/137353.stm | work=BBC News | title=Virgin Web hoax was 'moral lesson' | date=July 22, 1998 }}</ref> – may technically qualify, but are rarely discussed in the same context.)
==Operating concept of virginity==
Female virginity may either be defined solely according to the presence or absence of a [[hymen]],{{Dubious|date=July 2018}} or else according to more ambiguous, philosophical criteria.
In many societies, for a woman to [[dating (activity)|date]] or have [[boyfriend]]s – even if refraining from full [[sexual intercourse]] – would already be viewed as a violation of traditional values. (See [[technical virginity]]; [[honor killing]].) On the other hand, [[lesbian]] sexual activity would not normally be an object of concern. Meanwhile, a [[rape]] victim would be viewed as having lost her virginity by force.
An ancient wedding ritual, east European Slavic, involves relatives of the bride and/or groom waiting to receive the bloody sheet on which the bride was "deflowered", as "proof" of her former virginity (which would often be specified in the [[marriage contract]]). Techniques to simulate the bleeding and/or physical sensation of rupture are equally ancient. In rural Egypt, chicken blood is used if – for whatever reason – there is no real blood on the wedding night. The bloody sheet is then shown to the neighborhood as proof of virginity "deflowering".<ref>{{cite journal | last=Gwilliam | first= Tassie |title=Female Fraud: Counterfeit Maidenheads in the Eighteenth Century. | journal=Journal of the History of Sexuality |volume= 6 |issue= 4 | pages=518–548 |date=April 1996 | pmid=11618773 |jstor= 4617220 }}</ref>
==Methods of detection== {{Main|Virginity test}}
Several methods of "virginity fraud detection" claim to be available, but cannot adequately determine the status of virginity.
#Inspection to determine whether [[Hymenorrhaphy|hymen restoration surgery]] has been performed, and/or the vagina's general state of elasticity. In many societies, such inspections have traditionally been conducted by older female relatives of the prospective groom, but are increasingly performed by doctors, who may issue certificates of virginity for the benefit of the groom's family. Also, digital inspection may fail to detect [[surgical suture]] which are visible only by means of specialized medical instruments. However, this cannot adequately prove virginity. As the hymen and vagina are elastic, there have been cases where women have actually given birth and had their hymen return to its original state. Additionally, hymens can be broken through nonsexual activity such as horseback riding. #[[Background check]]s by a [[private detective]] aimed at uncovering a woman's romantic and/or medical history. This unfortunately relies on reporting of people who may have a score to settle with the woman being investigated. A number of attempts at virginity fraud are exposed by a woman's contact with medical clinics specializing in hymen restoration procedures.
==Public response==
In the West, awareness of hymen replacement surgery has led to criticisms of the procedure, on the grounds that it is medically unnecessary and contributes to pernicious social practices; alongside recognition that women's reasons for undergoing it are not frivolous (as might be claimed of other forms of elective plastic surgery). Little, if any, concern has been expressed for the intended victims of virginity fraud. Muslim responses have questioned the motives of women undergoing the procedure, as well as of prospective grooms whose attitudes have made the procedure so prevalent.
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.altmuslim.com/a/a/a/3334|title=A woman’s burden of proof|author=Rafia Zakaria|date=October 14, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609101333/http://www.altmuslim.com/a/a/a/3334|archivedate=June 9, 2011}}</ref>
In 2006, a French Muslim man in [[Lille, France|Lille]] sought an [[annulment]] on the grounds that his bride (also Muslim) turned out not to be a virgin. She denied having misled him, but did not contest the appeal, which was duly granted. In 2009, amidst a wave of media attention, French justice minister [[Rachida Dati]] ordered the government to appeal this decision (on the grounds that an important element of French public policy was at issue). [[Ronald Sokol]], in an editorial for the ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'', writes that
::The question was whether the woman's virginity was an essential element of the marriage contract. If it was, then the contract could be annulled. If it was not, then the couple was validly married.<ref name="CSMonitor">{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Commentary/Opinion/2009/0303/p09s01-coop.html|title=The curious case of chastity fraud|first=Ronald|last=Sokol|date=3 March 2009|publisher=|via=Christian Science Monitor}}</ref>
The appeals court reversed the judgment. Sokol continues:
::The government argued that the wife's virginity was not an essential condition because her unchaste past has no effect on married life. The judges agreed. Even if she had lied, they said, it did not matter, as a woman's lies about her past love affairs are not matters essential to her married life. In short, a woman's past is her own.<ref name="CSMonitor"/> It became known as the "Virginity Lie" case.<ref>{{cite news | url= http://blogs.reuters.com/faithworld/2008/06/24/new-french-muslim-chief-on-the-virginity-lie-case/ | work=Reuters | title=New French Muslim chief on the "virginity lie" case | date=June 24, 2008}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Artificial hymen]] * [[Born-again virgin]] * [[Genital modification and mutilation]] * [[Hymenotomy]] * [[Vaginoplasty]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/11/world/europe/11virgin.html?_r=2&scp=1&sq=hymen&st=nyt&oref=slogin | work=The New York Times | title=In Europe, Debate Over Islam and Virginity | first1=Elaine | last1=Sciolino | first2=Souad | last2=Mekhennet | date=June 11, 2008}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/human_nature/2008/06/sex_lies_and_virginity_restoration.html|title=Sex, Lies, and Virginity Restoration|date=11 June 2008|publisher=Slate|author=William Saletan|accessdate=16 March 2017|via=Slate}}
